DOC.HEAD: Plane Hits Another While Landing, One Dies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: First name `Abert' in 3rd graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: Two single-engine airplanes collided as they tried to land at a small airport Sunday and one crashed, killing the pilot, officials said. The accident occurred around 1:30 p.m. when the planes tried to land on the same runway at Hooks Airport north of Houston. A plane flown by Abert Bulgawicz, 45, of Magnolia came down on top of a plane flown by Douglas Howze, 36, of Tomball, and severed the tail of Howze's plane with its propeller, said Harris County Constable Sgt. Michael Hardin. Howze's plane crashed, and he was killed. Bulgawicz and a passenger landed safely, Hardin said. The National Transportation Safety Board was investigating the accident.

DOC.HEAD: Experts Check Soviet Cargo Plane in Radioactive Scare
DOC.TEXT: Radiation safety experts checked a Soviet cargo plane Saturday after crew members reported canisters containing radioactive uranium hexafluoride might have broken open. No leak was found, officials said. State safety officials and the Portland Fire Bureau's hazardous materials team checked for radiation for more than two hours aboard the Antonov 124, which landed at Portland International Airport shortly before 1 p.m., said Doug Roberts, a spokesman for the Port of Portland. The material was then turned over to the company that contracted to bring it into the United States, Roberts said. Ray Paris, a radiation safety officer with the Oregon Health Division, said the 11 Soviet crew members became concerned when they spotted a milky white liquid collected on the floor under the nine canisters after the airplane landed. Paris said uranium hexafluoride is a white powder. When mixed with water, it gives off a vapor that can be fatal, he said. He said emergency crews checked the crew for respiratory problems, then checked two Customs agents, crew members and the airplane for radioactivity. All tests were negative, Paris said. He said experts determined the liquid formed as condensation on the outside of the canisters and froze during the flight. It melted as the airplane landed and dripped onto the floor, mixing with dust or dirt to form the milky white substance, Paris said. Uranium hexaflouride is a chemical compound formed when uranium ore is treated with sulfuric acid to extract uranium oxide. Roberts said the material was bound for a processing center in Washington state to be made into fuel for nuclear power plants.

DOC.HEAD: Storm Flips Tractor-Trailers, Cars; Minor Injuries Reported
DOC.TEXT: A severe storm spawning at least one tornado whipped through four counties Saturday night, flipping tractor-trailers and numerous cars, a state official said. No fatalities were reported by early Sunday. Bill Brock, director of the state Department of Emergency Management, said there were reports that seven tractor-trailers were upside-down at the intersection of interstates 59 and 459 in Birmingham. He said numerous cars also were reported flipped over. He said there were reports of minor injuries. Officials confirmed one tornado sighting in the west Alabama community of Carrollton. Brock said emergency officials were trying to confirm reported tornado sightings in Tuscaloosa, Jefferson, St. Clair and Shelby counties. The storm system moving through the state Saturday evening could have spawned multiple tornadoes, Brock said. Officials would probably have to wait for daylight on Sunday to confirm the reports, he said. Brock said there were widespread power outages in the Birmingham area, and at least one shelter had been opened in west Birmingham.

DOC.HEAD: New Orleans Mayor Wins Re-Election
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to UPDATE with final results; picks up 3rd graf, Barthelemy, New ...'.
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Sidney Barthelemy won a second term in a primary election Saturday over a white challenger after a campaign marked on both sides by accusations of race-baiting. In complete but unofficial returns, Bathelemy had 79,995 votes, or 55 percent, to 65,047, or 44 percent, for his fellow Democrat Donald Mintz. Two other candidates split the remaining 1 percent. Barthelemy, New Orleans' second black mayor, smiled broadly as he took the podium for a victory statement but became more serious as he called for New Orleans to join together after a divisive campaign. ``We are in difficult times. We have laid the foundations for the future. But we cannot build a great city divided,'' he said. ``We all must work together.'' Barthelemy, 47, did not announce victory until his 46-year-old opponent, an attorney who had never before run for office, conceded defeat. ``Sidney, to you, congratulations and best wishes. If permitted, I look forward to working with you in the days ahead,'' Mintz told supporters at another hotel. Barthelemy avoided a runoff by winning more than half the vote. Ed Renwick, who was Barthelemy's pollster and WWL-TV's analyst, said Mintz needed 80 percent of the white vote and 20 percent of the black vote but got about 75 percent of the white vote and 15 percent of the black. Turnout was predicted at 55 percent to 60 percent of New Orleans' 237,000 registered voters, more than 54 percent of whom are black. Recent polls showed Barthelemy had erased Mintz's early lead and was about a dozen percentage points ahead. Herman J. ``Buster'' Bustamente, a Democrat, and black businessman Rudy E. Mills Sr., an independent, also ran.

_greater than Barthelemy's easygoing, conciliatory style contrasted with the hard-hitting intensity of Mintz, who resigned as head of the city's dock board to make the race. Mintz and Barthelemy denied the allegations of race-baiting and called them evidence that the other side was losing and desperate for an issue. Barthelemy, who was Louisiana's first black state senator and city councilman at large since Reconstruction, accused Mintz of being behind fliers depicting Barthelemy as an Uncle Tom. One shows him with a half-white face; the other shows him robbing the grave of the late Ernest Dutch Morial, New Orleans' first black mayor. Mintz, who is Jewish and wears a lapel pin showing black and white hands interlinked, vehemently denied the allegations, boasting of a strong civil rights record, including an Urban League award to his law firm. ``The mayor who said he wanted to bring people together has sought to divide them,'' Mintz said. He said some of Barthelemy's radio advertisements catered to anti-white racism, and he accused the mayor of anti-Semitic campaigning because of a flier saying Mintz's civil rights credentials apparently did not apply to blacks. Barthelemy called the anti-Semitism allegation ridiculous, noting that he has appointed Jews and received a B'nai B'rith award. Despite the sharp disagreements, the campaign drew relatively little attention as it competed with the Christmas holidays, a record freeze, the Sugar Bowl and the Super Bowl. There was never much interest in the issues: the city's high crime rate, unemployment _ which was above 10 percent for much of 1988 before falling to 6.9 percent in December 1989 _ and the candidates' experience and competence. Until late in December, most of the interest was focused on Morial, who served from 1978 to 1986 and was widely expected to run until Dec. 14, when he announced that he would not. From then until his death Dec. 23, interest centered on whether he would endorse either Mintz, a protege of his, or Barthelemy, who often battled with him when Barthelemy was a city councilman.

DOC.HEAD: Low-Level Alert Declared at Pennsylvania Nuclear Plant
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE that alert declared over at 12:25 a.m. EST; picks up 7th graf, `The county agency ...'.
DOC.TEXT: Faulty circuit breakers triggered a low-level alert for more than six hours Saturday at a nuclear plant in central Pennsylvania, but no radiation was released, Lt. Gov. Mark Singel said. Fire and ambulance crews were called to Susquehanna Steam Heating Station, but no injuries were reported and no employees were evacuated from the plant. ``It is not all that serious,'' said Karl Abraham, a spokesman for the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. ``There is no threat to the public at all or to the workers in the plant.'' Singel said the circuit breaker failures occurred during a routine safety check at the plant, and a valve on a cooling water line did not reopen. Water temperatures in the reactor system climbed from a normal of about 200 degrees to a high of 252 degrees. The plant was not operating at the time of the safety check. ``The water temperature was rising and there was an insufficient flow of water through the system,'' Singel said at a news conference at the state Capitol in Harrisburg. ``It is important to note that the incident has been completely contained within the reactor containment.'' The Level 2 alert declared at 5:53 p.m. meant that a problem had arisen that could affect the safety of plant operations, said Jim Siracuse of the Luzerne County Emergency Management Agency. A Level 4 alert is the most severe. The incident was declared over at 12:25 a.m. The county agency declared the alert because of the heat level problems within Unit 1. The reactor was shut down Thursday due to a leak in the plant's hydraulic control system. The problems were not related, according to plant spokesman Ira Caplan. Plant workers were working late Saturday to cool the reactor water through another system, according to Caplan. No water or steam was released. Abraham said the unit would not be restarted until NRC and plant officials had determined the cause of the problem. John Comey of the Pennsylvania Emergency Management Agency said only three or four Level 2 alerts have occurred in Pennsylvania since the March 1979 accident at Three Mile Island. All emergency response personnel in Luzerne and Lackawana Counties and all municipalities within a 10-mile radius of the plant have been activated and called into their offices, according to Comey. The plant in Salem Township 15 to 20 miles southwest of Wilkes-Barre is owned and operated by Pennsylvania Power & Light.

DOC.HEAD: Two Men Arrested in Slayings of Family
DOC.TEXT: Two men were arrested Saturday in the slayings of a farm couple and their two children whose bound bodies were found in their burning home, officials said. Anthony Carr, 24, of Clarksdale and Robert Simon Jr. 26, of Memphis, Tenn., were being held Saturday night at the Clarksdale Police Department on charges of capital murder. They were arrested shortly after 4 p.m. in Clarksdale, about 70 miles south of Memphis, Tenn., said Lt. Kenny Dickerson, a Highway Patrol investigator. Carl Webster Parker, 58, and his wife, Bobbie Jo, 45, and their children, Charlotte Jo, 9, and Gregory, 12, apparently walked in on a burglary of their home Friday night, authorities said. Investigators said they suspect the fire was set intentionally to cover the killings and destroy evidence. Earlier in the evening, the family had attended Bible study at Riverside Baptist Church in Clarksdale, where they were members, their pastor said. Their house is 15 miles from Clarksdale, and their nearest neighbors are more than a quarter-mile away. All were shot between two and four times at close range at about 10:30 p.m., said Quitman County Coroner J.W. Jenkins. He said two guns were used. Jenkins said the girl was raped. ``It looked like she had broken loose and tried to run,'' he said. The Lambert Volunteer Fire Department received a call between 11:15 p.m. and 11:30 p.m. Friday that the Parkers' home was burning, Assistant Fire Chief Chris Dancy said. Firefighters pulled the bodies of the father and two children from the home before fire gutted it, Dancy said. The three bodies were in a rear room ``within 5 feet of each other,'' Jenkins said. After the fire was extinguished, Bobbie Jo Parker's body was found in a back bedroom.

DOC.HEAD: Residents Vote to Lower Tax Bills
DOC.TEXT: By an overwhelming margin, voters decided Saturday to lower their tax bills by rolling back a city property tax hike. The measure to cut the hike from 12.1 percent to 8 percent was passed by a vote of 76,167 to 42,673 in unofficial results, the San Antonio City Clerk's office said. The measure was hotly debated in the weeks preceding the election. A rollback will cost the city $3.9 million in revenue. Mayor Lila Cockrell and the Hispanic Chamber of Commerce had opposed the rollback. The chamber said it would endanger economic expansion. Election officials had predicted a heavy turnout because it drew more absentee voters than any previous city election. When the two-week absentee voting period ended Tuesday, 53,328 people had cast early ballots. Voters in south Texas' Kleberg County and its county seat, Kingsville, also rolled back tax hikes Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: Armenian Quake Relief Flight Canceled
DOC.TEXT: A flight intended to bring supplies to Armenian earthquake victims was canceled just hours before takeoff Saturday, with relief officials saying the Soviet government refused to let their plane land. Members of the United Armenian Fund, a relief organization, said they were told that ``authorities in Moscow canceled the earthquake relief flight ... citing `technical reasons.''' The flight carrying space heaters donated by the U.S. Department of Defense, medical supplies, food and winter clothing was scheduled to take off from Los Angeles International Airport at 3 p.m. The UAF previously shipped three loads of relief supplies by plane to Soviet Armenia, which was devastated by a 1988 earthquake that killed thousands. ``Doctors and relief agencies anxiously await this crucial cargo,'' the group said in a statement. ``The UAF will take immediate steps to convey our strong objections to all participating parties, demanding an immediate resumption of flights.''

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Gather For Rally Ahead of Key Communist Party Plenum
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of demonstrators poured into a Moscow park Sunday for a rally mounted by pro-democracy groups on the eve of a Communist Party meeting expected to consider a multiparty system. Police blocked off major streets in downtown Moscow in anticipation of the legal march. People were gathering at Gorky Park early Sunday afternoon, and police said the marchers were expected to head to a square in central Moscow near the Kremlin for the rally. Among the groups organizing the event were the Russian and Moscow Popular Fronts, the Association of Moscow Voters, as well as the progressive Memorial group. One objective of the rally is to coordinate pro-democracy groups ahead of elections on March 4 for the parliament of the Russian Federated Republic, the largest in the Soviet Union. The rally comes one day before a key Communist Party plenum where Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is expected to ask the Central Committee to accept the possibility of competing political parties.

DOC.HEAD: Some 9.7 million People Jailed in Year Ending June 1988
DOC.TEXT: About 9.7 million people were thrown in a jail cell in the United States during the year that ended June 30, 1988, the Justice Department said Sunday. During the same year, some 9.6 million people were released from jail, and both numbers represented increases of 20 percent over 1983 figures, said the Office of Justice Statistics study. The average jail stay was three days, with 39 percent of inmates spending one day or less behind bars, 23 percent spending two to four days and 10 percent spending five to seven days, the study said. About 3 percent served more than six months and 1 percent spent more than a year behind bars. On June 30, 1988, the jail population totaled 343,569, or 144 of every 100,000 Americans, the study said. That rate was 47 percent higher than the 98 per 100,000 five years earlier. The study focused on local jails, defined as locally administered confinement facilities holding people awaiting trial or sentenced to terms usually of a year or less. About 51 percent of the people in jail had not been convicted of any crime when they were incarcerated, while 49 percent had been convicted, the same level as in 1983, the study found. The census did not include facilities in Connecticut, Delaware, Hawaii, Rhode Island and Vermont that combine jails with prisons, which are state or federal institutions. The study did not indicate the main charges of the 9.7 million brought into custody. Among the study's findings: _Jail populations in Southern states grew 61 percent between 1983 and 1988, to a total of 143,751 on June 30, 1988, while jail populations in the West increased 58 percent to 91,559; the Northeast jail population grew by 57 percent to 57,613 and the Midwest grew by 28 percent to 50,646. _The states with the largest percentage increase between June 30, 1983, and the same day on 1988 were Nevada, up 149 percent; Arizona, 104 percent; Florida and Texas, 93 percent; New Jersey 86 percent; Tennessee, 81 percent. _The only places where jail populations declined were Alaska, down 27 percent, and Washington, D.C., which reclassified an institution from a jail to a prison. _The highest rates of jail inmates per 100,000 state residents were in Georgia, 276; Louisiana, 255; Florida, 229; California, 227; Tennessee, 222; and Nevada, 222. _The lowest rates per 100,000 state residents were in Iowa, 37; North Dakota, 43; Maine, 56; Nebraska, 72; and New Hampshire and South Dakota, both 73. _The female jail population rose 93 percent during the five-year period to 30,411 on June 30, 1988. Women still represented only 9 percent of the total jail population, compared with 7 percent in 1983. The male population rose 51 percent to 313,158. _The percentage of juveniles in adult jails declined from 0.8 percent in 1983 to 0.5 percent in 1988, reflecting a 3 percent drop for boys and a 4 percent drop for girls. _The racial breakdown of inmates was 43 percent non-Hispanic whites, 41 percent non-Hispanic blacks, 15 percent Hispanics and 1 percent either American Indians, Alaska natives, Asians or Pacific Islanders. _Of the 667 people who died in jail during the year ending June 30, 1988, a total of 284 (43 percent) were suicides, 274 (41 percent) were illnesses not including AIDS, 66 (10 percent) died of AIDS, 10 (1 percent) were homicide victims and 33 (5 percent) died of other causes including accidents. _Jail capacity increased 30 percent to 339,633 beds between 1983 to 1988, and the amount of rated capacity that was occupied totaled 101 percent in 1988, up from 85 percent five years earlier. However, about 40,000 inmates, some 12 percent of the jail population on June 30, 1988, were being held for other correctional authorities, including some 26,500 held because of overcrowding elsewhere.

DOC.HEAD: Panamanians Debate Whether U.S. Forces Should Remain to Defend Canal
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. invasion of Panama has once more raised the issue of whether the United States will maintain a military presence beyond the year 2000, when the American bases must close. President Guillermo Endara has abolished Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's military, leaving open the question about who would defend the Panama Canal. Endara has made no public statement about the issue of the bases. The newspaper Panama America newspaper recently suggested the U.S.-Panama treaties be renegotiated to allow American payments in exchange for keeping American military bases. The 1977 treaties provide for the possibility of new agreements on defense of the waterway. Some Panamanians believe the United States must continue to handle the canal's security after the year 2000. The Spanish-language newspaper said, ``The optimum benefit of leasing the bases would be the possibility of charging (rent) even before the year 2000.'' Although Panama collects no rent from the United States, the U.S. bases mean nearly $100 million a year for Panama's economy in services purchased and other expenditures. Some Panamanian military sources say the 58-mile canal is indefensible because of the immense territory it covers and that the United States would need only a token security force. Some U.S. military sources say the United States might maintain Howard Air Base, just outside of Panama City, and the Rodman Naval Base. The treaties did away with the old Panama Canal Zone, a 10-mile stretch across the country along the canal that was U.S. territory, and stipulate that the canal will be turned over to Panama on Dec. 31, 1999, when the last American soldier is to go home. U.S. bases have been in Panama since the beginning of the century. The United States now maintains 10 military installations in Panama as part of the Southern Command with 12,000 soldiers. Another 12,000 were sent in during the invasion. Panamanians, who approved the treaties in a plebiscite organized by former dictator Omar Torrijos, do not dare ask for a revision of the treaties for fear of sounding anti-nationalist. The topic was taboo before the U.S. invasion Dec. 20. The United States said it invaded and toppled Noriega because his government had become a threat to U.S. interests and the operation of the canal, and to bring him to trial on U.S. drug-trafficking charges. Noriega claimed the U.S. government wanted to get rid of him because he opposed U.S. plans to renege on the treaties and maintain its large military installations in Panama. The United States does not want to appear as if it is going back on its word. It has said repeatedly that it intends to abide by the treaties. ``I personally do not feel that the United States needs a large military presence in Panama after the year 2000,'' said one U.S. Army officer who has been in Panama for years. ``A large military presence when the world situation is changing, could be a political liability for the United States,'' he said, speaking on condition he not be idenfitied. ``The United States would be criticized as an expansionist power.'' Maj. Gen. Marc Cisneros, commander of U.S. Army South, the ground forces in charge of protecting the canal, says the United States will meet its obligations to leave on schedule. ``It is the intention of the United States to fully comply with the canal treaties,'' Cisneros said. Cisneros emphasized the new Panamanian government, ``if it maintains a democratic system, will be able to run the canal as efficiently as we have.'' When Endara abolished Noriega's military forces, he established in the national police in their place. Last month, as stipulated by the agreements, a Panamanian became adminstrator of the Panama Canal Commission, the U.S. federal agency that adminsters the canal. About 30 ships daily use the canal.

DOC.HEAD: Storm Kills 29 People in France, West Germany
DOC.TEXT: A storm that swept through northern France and West Germany with hurricane-strength winds killed at least 29 people and caused widespread property damage, authorities in both countries said Sunday. The storm struck western France on Saturday with gusts up to 104 mph. The region's worst storm in 20 years left 23 people dead, authorities said. Among the buildings damaged was the 12th century cathedral at Chartres, one of the world's most magnificent Gothic structures. The wind peeled copper plates from the roof, leaving a 540-square-foot hole over the nave between the two bell towers of the church, 50 miles southwest of Paris. The state-run Electricite de France said that by midday Sunday, only 160,000 people remained without electricity of the 2 million or more whose power was cut at the height of the storm. Rail and air service, which had been severely disrupted by the high winds, fallen trees and electric wires, was back to normal Sunday. Several main highways also had been blocked temporarily. Officials said it was too early to estimate the cost of the damage. The storm also struck West Germany on Saturday with winds of up to 93 mph, leaving six people dead and several injured, including two people killed by falling trees in the Frankfurt area, officials said Sunday. High winds ripped off the roof of a sport hall near Offenbach and blew down one wall, injuring four spectators at a handball game. Downed trees blocked major highways for hours and delayed a number of trains. On Jan. 25, a storm with winds up to 110 mph killed a total of 95 people in Britain, Holland, Belgium, France, the Germanys and Denmark.

DOC.HEAD: Armenian Delegation Breaks Off Peace Talks with Azerbaijanis
With AM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Armenian negotiators broke off informal peace talks with Azerbaijanis and headed home Sunday after accusing them of pressuring Armenians to evacuate two villages in Azerbaijan, a participant said. Armenian leaders also instructed their negotiators in Riga, Latvia, that the Armenian All-National Movement had refused to ratify an agreement to seek a peaceful settlement of the conflict and exchange information on hostages. The talks, held without the participation of the Soviet government, began Friday with mediators from the people's fronts movements in the western republics of Latvia, Estonia and Lithuania. Direct talks followed on Saturday. ``Everything went well until there was a pause in the talks. Then the leaders of the Armenian All-National Movement in Yerevan told the negotiators to cut the talks,'' said Ints Upmacis, a Latvian People's Front leader present during the meeting. The Armenians headed for Yerevan early Sunday, Upmacis said in a telephone interview. The Armenian political movement in Yerevan accused the Azerbaijan People's Front of pressing Armenian residents to evacuate the villages of Azad and Kamo in the Khanlar region of Azerbaijan, the official news agency Tass reported. The residents were told they were in danger of being attacked, and the Armenians claimed the army said it was unable to guarantee their safety, Upmacis said. ``The Armenian National Movement board does not find it possible to continue joint consultations in Riga,'' a statement issued by the movement's press center in Yerevan said. ``Joint consultations and talks can be possible in the future only on condition of the termination of such actions.'' When informed that the Armenians were planning to leave the talks, the Azerbaijani negotiators agreed to try and verify the Armenian claim, but Communist Party officials and Soviet army officials reached in the Azerbaijani capital of Baku said they had no information to support the charges. The Azerbaijani delegation said it was ready to resume talks with the Armenians and departed for a meeting of representatives of pro-democracy groups in the Lithuanian capital of Vilnius, Upmacis said. Leaders of the Azerbaijani People's Front in Baku could not be immediately reached to comment on the Armenian decision to break off the talks. Outbreaks of ethnic violence have plagued the two southern republics for two years following Armenia's demand for annexation of Nagorno-Karabakh, a predominantly Armenian enclave located inside Azerbaijan. The latest round of violence began Jan. 13, resulting in the deaths of at least 214 people and the evacuation of thousands of ethnic Armenians who lived in Azerbaijan. The Soviet Army marched into Baku on Jan. 20 in response to the violence and the volatile developments prompted leaders of the three Baltic Fronts to propose peace talks out of concern that the conflict could jeopardize their own peaceful drive for democracy and independence in the Baltics. Tass said extremist elements in the Azerbaijani People's Front continued to disrupt efforts of the Communist Party, the army and other bodies to stabilize the situation in Baku. During the weekend, extremists using two armored personnel carriers fired at helicopters, but there were no injuries, the agency reported.

DOC.HEAD: Retirees Charged with Son's Murder in Deadly Double-Cross
DOC.TEXT: Police say Christopher Morris plotted with his parents to kill his ex-wife to collect $35,000 in insurance. When they found out the policy had lapsed, authorities allege, the parents killed him instead _ to collect a $70,000 policy. Theron and Leila Mary Morris, transplanted snowbirds from Detroit with a poodle named Pepe, kept a well-tended yard in their mobile home community. They were regular churchgoers, friendly, quick to lend a hand with yardwork. And they're charged with murder, accused of killing their 42-year-old son in a deadly double-cross. Police say the Morrises schemed with their ex-convict son to kill his former wife, Sharon, and her 10-year-old daughter for the insurance. But they turned on their son after they learned that coverage had lapsed, authorities say. The Morrises also were angry their son sold them bogus cocaine for $1,000 that they had intended to resell, investigators say. The couple and Martin Rector, their son's roommate and onetime prison buddy who is accused of being the triggerman, then conned a drifter with drinking and blackout problems into confessing to the crime, police say. The drifter, 40-year-old John Woods, was released from jail after the three others confessed Wednesday. ``I've been doing homicide for 12 years,'' said sheriff's Lt. Tom Carney. ``It's the strangest, most cold-blooded murder I've ever seen. It seems they were upstanding citizens, never had a brush with the law. They look just like any other grandparents you would find any place in the country.'' The Morrises' lawyer, Douglas Lambeth, says a different story will emerge in court: that the Morrises were afraid of Rector and went along out of fear. ``They talked to police,'' Lambeth acknowleged. ``That's unfortunate for them. But it's not admissible in court. I tell my clients that the fish would still be swimming in the ocean if they kept their mouths shut.'' The alleged murder scheme stunned residents of the Morrises' mobile home community, north of Fort Lauderdale. ``They were good neighbors,'' said John Brennan, a retired school administrator from Binghamton, N.Y. ``He was a good church member. When we returned in winter with all that yardwork, he was the first one to come over and help you clean up.'' Theron Morris, 76, a retired Chrysler Corp. engineer, and his wife, 62, who worked for United Air Lines for 23 years, moved to Florida four years ago. Their son was released from prison late last year after serving time on drug and assault charges. Neighbors said the Morrises were trying to help him overcome a cocaine habit. They housed him, fed him, bought him a car and found him a place to live. But there was tension. ``There was arguing, yelling. ... It was kind of like a family feud,'' said Michael Kern, 23, who lives across the street. Dorothy Brennan, another neighbor, recalled Theron Morris ordering his son out of the house and telling him not to return. Police say Chris Morris and Rector hatched a scheme to kill Sharon Morris and her daughter. The two later recruited the elder Morrises, police say. But when Rector went to Sharon Morris' house to kill her, posing as a flower delivery man, she wouldn't come to the door because Rector was not in uniform, said Carney. Then, police say, the plotters discovered that a $35,000 insurance policy on Sharon had lapsed. So the target of the murder plot shifted to Chris, who was insured for $70,000. On the evening of Jan. 8, the younger Morris went with Rector to his parents' home. Once there, police say, Rector pulled out a .38-caliber revolver with a silencer and ordered Morris to the floor. Morris' father then bound him with duct tape and helped load him into the back seat of the car, but Chris Morris broke free and was shot three times by Rector. They chased Chris and told him they would take him to the hospital, but instead they took him to the nearby town of Coconut Creek, shot him three more times and left him in the car, police said. Detectives said Mrs. Morris followed in another car, picked up her husband and Rector and took them home. Chris' body was found the next day. The Morrises told neighbors he was killed by drug dealers. Leila Morris ``came over and put her arms around me and cried and cried,'' recalled Mrs. Brennan. Sharon Morris attended her ex-husband's funeral, unaware she had once been a target. The Morrises housed and fed Rector after Chris' death, gave him an alibi for the night and said their son had gone out for beer and cigarettes. But police immediately suspected Rector and said that under questioning, Rector and the Morrises implicated each other, then ultimately confessed. The insurance money has not been paid. Carney said what struck him most was the way the Morrises described the events. ``They indicated that they had a rough life with him,'' the lieutenant said. ``They figured they could get rid of the problem child and pick up $70,000. ``But neither of them showed any remorse, any remorse about all of the details. It was almost like they were talking about strangers.''

DOC.HEAD: Mill Town's Future is in Corporate America's Hands
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Money in 6th graf is cq
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto AU1
DOC.TEXT: For the 7,000 residents of this turn-of-the-century paper mill town, the outcome of a corporate battle they don't pretend to understand is in the hands of business executives they don't know. Georgia-Pacific Corp. has made a $3.8 billion bid for Great Northern Nakoosa Corp., whose mill is the biggest employer in this remote, northern town. Since the takeover battle began in October, the paper giants have made promises and engaged in mudslinging to try to win the favor of Mainers. But the citizens of Millinocket don't know who to root for. ``Do I believe either one of them? No,'' said Fredericka Boynton, whose grandfather, father, husband and son worked in the mill. ``I think they're big corporations and playing that merger game, and I don't think we're going to win.'' ``People in the area have been pulled by their heartstrings,'' said Money McGibbon, whose husband worked at the mill for 33 years. ``They're just being tugged from one end to the other, and it's not fair.'' Atlanta-based Georgia-Pacific has accused Great Northern of financially starving Millinocket to the point where the aging mill may not have a future. If it wins the fight, Georgia-Pacific says, it will spend more than $1 million to determine whether it is feasible to make toilet paper, paper towels and paper napkins in Millinocket instead of paper used in books, telephone directories and the like. The mill, built in 1900, employs about 900 people, and Georgia-Pacific says a tissue-making operation could employ 215. The company said it does not have enough information on the Great Northern mills and woodlands to make commitments about the remaining jobs. Great Northern, based in Norwalk, Conn., but incorporated in Maine, has claimed Georgia-Pacific has a secret plan to sell the Millinocket operations as well as a newsprint mill in nearby East Millinocket and 2.1 million acres of Maine woodlands. Georgia-Pacific denies the accusation. Great Northern has promised $2.5 billion in improvements for Maine. Georgia-Pacific calls that a ``pipe dream.'' At a meeting last month, Georgia-Pacific executives tried to show their company would be a good corporate citizen. But townspeople wondered how life would change in this company town where Great Northern once meant a secure job. Residents acknowledged that Great Northern has put more effort and money into building up its southern mills in recent years. Employment has been cut in Millinocket. ``Before the problems started with Great Northern, you could go to school here and have a job for life at good wages,'' said retiree Francis Larkin, who spent his life working for the mill. ``The times when they helped us put in the foundations of our homes are gone,'' said Robert Boynton, Mrs. Boynton's husband, a retired Great Northern mechanical supervisor. Boynton said Great Northern still lends tools to those in need. ``If you want a paint brush, you can borrow a paint brush. If I need a couple of jacks, I'd go in and see the plant engineer,'' he said. ``I've never known them to refuse anybody. They'll let you borrow anything.'' Retirees worry about their benefits if the mill changes ownership, and a Georgia-Pacific executive acknowledged at the meeting that he had no answers. Union leaders and rank-and-file workers worry that jobs could be lost if the merger goes through. ``This is all we have got is the Great Northern Paper Co., and that's all we have known for years,'' Mrs. McGibbon said. ``We're a little bit leery of someone we don't know.''

DOC.HEAD: Walesa: Probably Will Not Seek Re-election
With AM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Solidarity leader Lech Walesa said Sunday he probably will step down in April as leader of the union he founded as a shipyard electrician and ultimately led into the halls of government. Walesa, 46, who has served as leader of the East bloc's first independent trade union since its founding in 1980, made the statement during a speech before 1,000 supporters after a Mass in his home city of Gdansk. At one point during the rally at St. Brygida's Church, Walesa was interrupted by heckling from a group of about 50 young radicals. Walesa has often spoken about his desire to retire from the burdens of the union. Some people around him suspect he is preparing to make a bid for Poland's presidency, replacing Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, if Poland's constitution is altered this year requiring new presidential elections. ``I am publicly saying that I will not run for leadership at the regional congress (scheduled this week in Gdansk) and, most probably, at the national congress either,'' Walesa said. He had told a news conference Thursday that he was ``tired'' of his activity and would like to rest for at least two years. But he stressed then that if radicals threatened to take over Solidarity, he would stay in the job. Solidarity's national congress is to meet in April in Gdansk. The gathering will be only the second in Solidarity's history. The union managed to hold one congress in September and October 1981 before it was suppressed in the martial-law crackdown. Walesa led the union into a series of talks with the Communist government that led to the union re-legalization last year, its participation in elections and then ultimately control of the government. Since it was legalized, its membership has reached about 2 million, or only one-fifth of its 1981 strength. Regional congresses have been held in various cities over the past two months to select delegates to the national congress. After Walesa made his comments about not running for union leadership, some of the young radicals applauded and began chanting, ``Solidarity Without Walesa.'' The radicals represented the Confederation for an Independent Poland, the Federation of Fighting Youth and a self-styled group of ``anarchists.'' The protesters, using a bullhorn, accused Walesa of limiting democracy. One of the youths shouted: ``If you continue like this you will end up like Ceausescu,'' a reference to Nicolae Ceausescu of Romania, who was overthrown in a violent revolt last year and executed. Asked by spectators about his opinion on the daylong takeover of Gdansk province Communist Party headquarters last weekend by a similar group of radicals, Walesa said: ``This is not the right way. Every government will use force in the face of anarchy and danger and must do so. If there is a threat to the state or the city, then I will get up myself with my belt and beat you. ``You cannot play with Poland. You have to build it,'' he said. ``If we continue with such methods we will get no where because some general may explode and take advantage of the situation.''

DOC.HEAD: Geraldine Ferraro's Mother Dies At 84
DOC.TEXT: Antonetta Ferraro, mother of former vice presidential candidate Geraldine Ferraro, has died. She was 84. Mrs. Ferraro died Friday at her daughter's Forest Hills home of emphysema and cancer. ``I always said I had two role models in life,'' Ms. Ferraro told New York Newsday. ``One was Eleanor Roosevelt and one was Antonetta Ferraro. She worked all her life. She worked in sweatshops when they were really sweatshops. She learned a trade at 13 that put me through law school.'' Mrs. Ferraro, whose husband, Dominick, died in 1943, had left the hospital two months ago to be with her daughter and her family. The family has set up the Antonetta Ferraro Scholarship Fund at Marymount Manhattan College in Manhattan, where Ms. Ferraro graduated. ``It's a scholarship fund for girls who have been raised (solely) by their mothers,'' said Ms. Ferraro, the Democrat nominee for vice-president in 1984. ``My mother felt she never had an education, but I always told her she did pretty well by me.'' In addition to her daughter, Mrs. Ferraro is survived by a son, Carl, and six grandchildren. The funeral was set for Tuesday in the New York City borough of Queens.

DOC.HEAD: Rushdie Appeals to Moderate Moslems, Says No Offense Intended
DOC.TEXT: In a rare public comment from his enforced seclusion, author Salman Rushdie appealed to Moslems on Sunday to reconsider their opposition to ``The Satanic Verses,'' saying he feels their pain but cannot retract his book. In a 7,000-word essay, which he said was the hardest piece of writing he had ever done, Rushdie said he never intended to blaspheme Islam and regrets the racial tensions that followed the novel's publication. But Rushdie also wrote in The Independent on Sunday that Moslems who burned his books and staged violent demonstrations were partly responsible. Rushdie criticized the British government for not prosecuting a Moslem leader who reportedly advocated his death. Rushdie, a naturalized Briton who was born into a Moslem family in India, has been in hiding under British police guard since Feb. 14, 1989, when Iranian Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini called for Rushdie's death. The decree was not lifted when Khomeini died in June. Reaching out to ``the great mass of ordinary, decent, fair-minded Moslems,'' Rushdie said he recognized that many of them were shocked and pained by his book, just as he was hurt by their rejection of it. He asked them ``to renounce blood; not to let Moslem leaders make Moslems seem less tolerant than they are.'' ``Perhaps a way forward might be found through the mutual recognition of that mutual pain,'' he suggested. His olive branch was rejected by Liaqat Hussain, general secretary of the Council of Mosques in Bradford, northern England, which has led the campaign to ban ``The Satanic Verses.'' ``Mr. Rushdie has suffered no pain. It is Moslems who have lost their lives and suffered injuries,'' Hussain said. Six people were killed in India and Pakistan during demonstrations against the book. ``I would not go into hiding for my beliefs ... he should be brave enough to face the world for his principles,'' Hussain added. Sunday's essay was Rushdie's fullest defense of his book and account of his predicament since he went into hiding, although he has given a handful of interviews and referred to his plight in book reviews. Saying he regretted that the book caused offense, Rushdie added: ``Would I have written it differently if I had known what would happen? Truthfully, I don't know. Would I change any of the text now? I would not. It's too late.'' Rushdie said the British government should have prosecuted Kalim Siddiqui who reportedly urged Moslems meeting in Manchester, northern England, to raise their hands if they agreed with Khomeini's death sentence. ``I find it upsetting that it's seen to be all right for people to go around the country calling for my death,'' Rushdie wrote. Moslem leaders have repeatedly attacked Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's government for refusing to ban the book or prosecute Rushdie. The Independent on Sunday's literary editor, Blake Morrison, reported that Rushdie looked ``healthy and relaxed'' when they met at an undisclosed location in England on Wednesday for a separate interview. Rushdie said that in hiding he missed most the ordinary things _ ``not being able to walk down a street, not being able to browse in a bookshop, not being able to go to a movie.'' He said at times he could not work, but now his writing is going well, including a children's book, essays and the synopsis for a novel. He said he watches a lot of television, and has become ``an addict of American football'' broadcast in Britain late at night.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Amtrak Cut Proposal Rekindles Old Battle
DOC.TEXT: For the sixth consecutive year the Republican administration in Washington has proposed cutting off all subsidy for Amtrak passenger rail service. And Congress, for the sixth straight year, is expected to refuse to go along. President Bush last week carried on a longstanding tradition established by his predecessor by proposing to cut the federal Amtrak subsidy. The move would leave Amtrak about 28 percent shy of what it says it needs to operate for fiscal 1991. Legislators in the Northeast accuse Bush of ignoring the progress Amtrak has made in reducing its dependence on federal money and of pursuing a policy that will lead to more crowded highways and airports. ``It's a terrible decision,'' said Rep. Bruce Morrison, D-Conn. ``With the amount of money that is to be saved compared to the extraordinary public investment that's already gone into improving the rail infrastructure ... it's really penny wise and pound foolish.'' Of Amtrak's $1.9 billion budget this year, $600 million was supplied by the federal government. In 1981, the federal government supplied about half of Amtrak's budget. ``We're talking about one B-2 worth of expenditures,'' Morrison said. New England is one of the heavy beneficiaries of the quasi-public rail line established in 1970 by Congress to replace failing private lines. In Connecticut, Amtrak carries 1.2 million passengers per year, and employs 727 state residents on a payroll of $25 million, according to Amtrak statistics. Some 422,000 Rhode Island passengers use the system each year and Amtrak employs 295 residents on $10 million in payroll. And in Massachusetts, where Amtrak also is responsible for commuter service, 1.4 million passengers use the Amtrak system along with 14 million commuters per year. Amtrak employs 1,710 Massachusetts residents and spends 55 million in payroll. Federal Railroad Administration spokeswoman Claire Austin said the administration opposes a subsidy. But she said Bush strongly supports rail transportation and she indicated there was no reason to believe the scenario played out in previous years would change. ``We've always requested no subsidy and Congress always makes an appropriation,'' Austin said. Unlike President Reagan, Austin said, Bush supports federal spending for research into high-speed rail technology, equipment and safety standards. ``That's a different twist that you have not seen in the Reagan administration,'' according to Austin. Rep. Christopher Shays, R-Conn., predicted Congress would again disagree with the president on the Amtrak subsidy issue. But Shays said Congress has the same goal: ``We will wean Amtrak from federal subsidies and we'll appropriate a little less.'' According to Amtrak, a gradual reduction in federal subsidies could be accomplished without cutting into rail service. ``We've said publicly, and it's mentioned in the president's budget, that Amtrak has a goal of being self-sufficient for operational costs by the year 2000,'' said Amtrak spokesman Clifford Black. The rail line will still need at least $150 million per year for capital improvements, Black said. For now, Morrison said, Amtrak depends on federal subsidies for survival and so does the region's transportation system. ``In the Northeast Corridor, the last thing we need to do is dump more cars and more air traffic into an already congested system,'' Morrison said.

DOC.HEAD: 70 Members of Banned Party Reported Arrested in Nepal
DOC.TEXT: Authorities arrested 70 members of the outlawed Nepali Congress Party as it prepared to launch a campaign demanding that political organizations be legalized in Nepal, a party spokesman said Sunday. Reports of harassment of other activists have been pouring in from local districts, and in some places authorities have succeeded in stopping the party's activities, spokesman Daman Dhunganahe said. Speaking at a news conference at party headquarters, he said the arrests had been made in 10 of the country's 75 districts, but so far no action had been taken against party activists in Katmandu, the capital. The leftist party, banned 29 years ago, decided recently to launch a nationwide campaign next week to demand restoration of a multiparty system. The Congress Party was voted into power in 1959, but was overthrown 18 months later in a royal takeover. The country's Western-style Parliament was dissolved, and Nepal adopted its present ``panchayat'' policy, which bans all political parties. Candidates elected to a national assembly must run as independents. The assembly elects a prime minister from among its members and a Council of Ministers, which advises the king, a powerful figure in Nepal who has the authority to declare a state of emergency or suspend the constitution. Denouncing the Congress Party's planned campaign, Prime Minister Marich Man Shrestha declared last month that the panchayat system ``is committed to ensure that all citizens enjoy equal civil rights in an unhindered fashion.'' He said the party was trying to force its version of democracy on Nepal ``when there already exists a working democracy in the country.''

DOC.HEAD: Retirees Cut Out of Huge Pension Profits
DOC.TEXT: The nation's burgeoning pension system owns a huge chunk of corporate America, but the benefits go to almost everyone but the retirees the funds are set up to serve. Typically described as a nest egg for millions of working Americans, pension funds also are being used to make a fast buck for stock brokers, pay off corporate debt and even pressure some corporations into having social consciences. The pension system, buoyed by the bull market of the 1980s, has grown into an economic force, rising from just $7 billion in assets in 1950 to $2 trillion today. About half that money is invested in stocks, with pension funds holding 25 percent of total equity in the U.S. economy. The multibillion-dollar investments make pension funds _ and those who manage them _ major players on Wall Street. ``It's not the retirees who are getting this money. It's the investment managers or traders, or owners,'' says Karen Ferguson, director of the Pension Rights Center, a public interest group. Documents and about two dozen interviews indicate that the basic goal of the pension laws, enacted by Congress to protect and benefit the retirees, has been eroded by the power pensions can broker on the stock market. Robert Monks, the head of the Washington-based pension consulting firm Institutional Shareholder Services, joined other experts in saying investment managers are pushed by all sides to make a quick profit. In fact, there appears to be a growing move by pension funds to put equity managers on performance-based fees. This encourages short-term trades that garner commissions for brokers and, the companies hope, new assets for the funds. The 1974 Employee Retirement Income Security Act, known as ERISA, says all investments must be made to benefit the pensioners. But the windfall made with pension fund assets rarely reaches the retiree. Companies are allowed to skim off profits through a maneuver known as ``reversions,'' and they are under no obligation to boost benefits when the funds prosper. ``All the increased volatility on the stock market system with pension plans hasn't contributed to value for the beneficiaries,'' Monks said. ``The people who are making money are the brokers, consultants, investment managers. You're not making money for the people you're supposed to be.'' Texaco, for example, nabbed $360.9 million in pension surpluses shortly after merging with Getty Oil Co. in 1984. Occidental Petroleum skimmed off $238 million from the pensions of its acquisition, Cities Service. Most pension plans provide a monthly income after retirement based on a portion of wages earned during the later years of service. In most cases, the basic benefits are neither boosted when investments do well, nor decreased when they do not. Some big businesses, however, do provide ``ad hoc'' cost-of-living increases at the discretion of management. Owens-Illinois Inc. of Toledo, Ohio, is one such company. Ronald C. Boller, the company's vice president and director of benefit finance, says it provides periodic benefit increases to its pensioners. But the increases are not directly related to the stock market, where 70 percent of Owen-Illinois' pension fund assets are invested. And Boller acknowledges that ``we've had a hell of a run in the markets, where most of the money is invested.'' ``Formally, technically, the obligation of the company _ the pension promise _ exists whether the market goes up, down or sideways,'' he says. Ms. Ferguson is among those who say the full surpluses should be passed on to the retirees, adding: ``Even at low inflation rates the value of a retiree's benefit will be cut in half in a lifetime without a cost-of-living adjustment.'' Michael S. Gordon, a Washington pension lawyer and contributor to the ERISA law, argues that reversions amount to ``pension barbarism.'' But proponents of reversions say the companies deserve the money as a reward for managing the investments well. ``What happens when the market goes bad? The employer is stuck with the liability,'' said New York pension attorney Jeffrey Mamorsky. That is only partially true. If the employer is unable to pick up the pension tab it falls to the federal government's Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation. That agency has a $1.5 billion deficit and, should it falter, taxpayers ultimately could shoulder the responsibility. Some pension analysts also are concerned about a growing trend to use the financial clout of the funds on Wall Street to further social and political goals. In their view, such investment strategies _ however laudable the intent _ conflict with ERISA's mandate that the money be invested solely for the benefit of the pensioners. This trend started about five years ago when many public funds, those covering public employees, called on their investment managers to get rid of stock in companies doing business in South Africa. Pressure also has been placed on some companies to respond to environmental concerns. The public pension funds in New York last year pushed Exxon Corp. to put an environmentalist on its board after the Valdez oil spill in Alaska. Texaco last year also agreed to nominate a director from a list submitted by the California Public Employee Retirement System. Gordon, with a strict interpretation of the ERISA law, says ``wooly-eyed social investment schemes'' should be avoided by private pension plans, where the goal is to act on behalf of the retirees. ``With public funds, if they can't come through with the benefits then the (state) legislatures will do some kind of tax,'' he said. ``With private plans, the employer is on the hook. ``If his assets aren't around to back it up then there's a crush on PBGC, which already is in trouble.''

DOC.HEAD: Teen-age Girl Who Received Historic Lung Assist Device Still `Critical'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT that operation took place in afternoon sted night, correct `supply' to `supplying;' ADDS 3 grafs with further detail on guidelines, seven-day limit.
DOC.TEXT: A teen-age girl who was the first human recipient of a pioneering lung assist device remained in critical condition Sunday at LDS Hospital. The girl received the IntraVascular Oxygenator _ an inch-wide, 20-inch-long bundle of plastic fibers that mimic the lung's task of supplying oxygen to the body _ during a two-hour operation Friday afternoon. The hospital would report only the girl's condition Sunday. A nursing supervisor, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the patient's family insists that no further information about the girl be released. The Salt Lake Tribune reported that the girl is 16. Guidelines approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration in September limit the implants to seven days in people with acute respiratory failure who have little other chance of survival. The IVOX is designed to give damaged lungs a chance to rest and recover before it is removed. Its developer, Dr. J.D. Mortensen of Salt Lake City, says while IVOX cannot really be called an artificial lung, it represents an important step toward eventual development of one. Implantation of the lung assist device involves insertion of the IVOX via the neck or groin into the inferior vena cava, the large vein that brings blood to the heart. Two tubes the diameter of a soda straw are attached to the IVOX bundle _ consisting of 900-1,200 hollow, porous fibers each about the diameter of a human hair _ and leave the body; one delivers oxygen to theAkKear-old Hoeflehner after edging Atle Skaardal of Norway and Franz Heinzer of Switzerland by 0.20 seconds. The Austrian, with a faultless run, completed the 3,100-meter distance in the winning time of 1 minute, 44.57 seconds. Hoeflehner, who had won the second downhill race of his career in Cortina in 1984, said Sunday he avoided mistakes that relegated him to third place in a downhill on the same track Saturday. ``I concentrated on the bottom part, which was the most difficult, and I avoided the errors which had cost me victory yesterday,'' Hoeflehner said. Two consecutive downhills were raced here to make up for canceled events in Chamonix and Saalbach. Sunday's victory _ the 10th of his career and following two wins in Val D'Isere last week _ strengthened Hoeflehner's lead in the World Cup downhill standings and boosted his chances to win this year's title. The Austrian has 131 points and, with only two races left in this year's competition, holds a commanding lead over Swiss all-rounder Pirmin Zurbriggen, second with 92 points. Zurbriggen, who turned 27 Sunday, was sixth. But he widened his World Cup overall lead to 270 points, 58 ahead of Norwegian Ole Kristian Furuseth, who did not start in the weekend races here. ``Helmut looked unbeatable today, but I made a decisive mistake in the bottom part,'' said Zurbriggen, shooting for a record-equaling fourth overall title before retiring in March. He had placed fifth in Saturday's race, in which hometown favorite Christian Ghedina captured his first ever World Cup victory. Ghedina was 15th Sunday. Skaardal was satisified with his performance. ``I fell short of a second victory, but a second place is something good in a World Cup race,'' said Skaardal, who won his first ever downhill in Kitzbuehel this year. Heinzer, who was tied with Skaardal in second place, said he missed a big opportunity to win his first race since Vail in 1988. ``I made a few, minor mistakes which still were decisive,'' Heinzer commented. His teammate Daniel Mahrer, second in Saturday's race behind Ghedina, edged a late Italian starter, Danilo Sbardellotto, for fourth place. American A.J. Witt, who had skied to a fourth-place finish Saturday, was 36th in Sunday's race, 2.55 seconds slower than the winner. Felix Belczyk of Canada was the best North American finisher, in 14th place, 0.86 seconds off the winning time. The next men's race will be a super-giant slalom Tuesday at Courmayeur, Italy.

DOC.HEAD: Breakaway Catholics To Allow Female Priests, Birth Control, Abortion
DOC.TEXT: The Rev. George Stallings said Sunday that his congregation, in ``taking control of its own destiny'' by breaking ties with the Roman Catholic Church, would encourage the ordination of women and allow birth control and abortion. Stallings, in defiance of church officials, last summer formed the Imani Temple, an independent African-American Catholic congregation. He announced his decision to break all ties with the Vatican last week. Stallings said the departure from Vatican authority would allow his congregation to set in place ``its own displine and laws, which will govern our activites.'' Stallings, after addressing his congregation of several hundred followers on Sunday, revealed some of those laws. ``We will allow for the ordination of women and we will allow for divorced and remarried Catholics to be in full communion without having to go through the tedious and potentially damaging annulment process,'' he said in an interview. ``We will also allow the use of birth control as well as allow women to decide whether or not to abort a life.'' In addition, he said the Imani Temple would permit ``optional celibacy, which means our priests will be able to decide whether or not they want to marry.'' Stallings, citing other occasions in which sects have broken away from the church, expressed confidence that the Lord would not abandon his church even if the Vatican does _ in the form of excommunication. ``Just as God has been with other Catholics in their declaration of independence from the Catholic Church, he will be with us,'' he told his congregation. Later, he said, ``Excommunication in its truest sense means to be cut off from communion with God. No church, no Pope, no power can separate anyone from God because God will not allow that to happen.'' He defended his church's stance on birth control and abortion, noting, ``The Bible has nothing to say about abortion or birth control. The positions we are taking are not counter-Biblical; they are allowed within the expression of faith.'' On the subject of ordaining women, he said, ``There is nothing in the Bible that says women can't be ordained ministers. We know from the scriptures that women are deaconesses. If anything, the scriptures advance the cause of women to the higher levels of ordination.''

DOC.HEAD: Quoth The Professor: Ravens Not So Solitary As Once Believed
DOC.TEXT: The usually shy, solitary raven turns out to be a gregarious bird in winter, flocking to noisy feasts on carcasses that serve as ``traveling discos'' because they let male ravens strut their stuff, a University of Vermont zoologist says. Bernd Heinrich, who has donned a bear costume to try to get closer to the big, black, bashful birds, gathered evidence for his book, ``Ravens in Winter,'' at his woodland cabin near Mount Blue State Park in western Maine. After more than five years' study and aided by a National Science Foundation grant, Heinrich wrote the first comprehensive study of interactions among the birds whose mysterious behavior has inspired centuries of folklore. Heinrich's work began when he observed about 15 ravens feasting noisily on a moose carcass near his cabin overlooking Maine's western mountains. Ravens are uncommon, solitary creatures that usually fly alone or in pairs; it seemed impossible to him that those birds, and those he saw feeding at other carcasses in subsequent days, each could have found the food individually. He was forced to conclude that the ravens apparently were sharing their valuable winter food sources by recruiting complete strangers. ``It was the most left-wing behavior I had ever heard of in a natural system,'' the zoology professor wrote. Over the years, Heinrich hauled countless deer and moose carcasses donated by game wardens uphill to his retreat, to be used as bait for his experiments. His field work and studies of marked, captive birds, led him to theorize that vagrant birds _ mostly juveniles passing through an area _ ``yell'' to alert one another about newly discovered food that often is defended by a resident pair of adults. Because the vagrants continue to call others in to feed, even after there are enough young birds present to overwhelm the adults, Heinrich says that the carcasses may also act as ``traveling discos'' where the birds can show off their bravery and ability to find food to potential mates. Heinrich believes that dominance is at the core of ravens' social behavior. In general, he says, the dominant birds tend to be males, which are larger than females. Ravens are shy, which is one reason there has been so little substantial research on them. Just the sight of an eyeball or the snap of a twig can send them soaring, Heinrich said. That shyness once led Heinrich to don a bear suit to see if he could get closer to his subjects. He knew that the birds sometimes allow wolves or coyotes to feed next to them, keeping a wary eye on their dinner guests but not flying away. ``I would have worn a big wolf suit or a big coyote suit if I'd had one,'' he explains in his cabin, where the bear suit still lies in a corner. ``But I figured I could most easily mimic a bear. And there are bears around here, so it was worth a shot, you know.'' Did it work? Heinrich grinned and chuckled. ``No. Uh-uh,'' he said. ``They weren't fooled for one second. They just all took off in alarm like I was a human.''

DOC.HEAD: Train Robbers Captured
DOC.TEXT: Authorities arrested 59 members of a gang that robbed trains in southern and central China for nearly two years, an official news report said Sunday. The nationally televised evening news showed four handcuffed gang members being led off a train in Zhengzhou, capital of Henan province in eastern China. The report said authorities confiscated Chinese cash worth the equivalent of tens of thousands of dollars from the gang after an eight-month investigation spanning 15 provinces. In one instance, the report said, gang members stole $8,500 from a passenger on a train to Shanghai. In another case, the gang beat a policeman patrolling a train and stole his gun. The report did not say how many people belonged to the gang. People publicly accused of crimes in China often receive lengthy prison sentences or are executed.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Reported Killed Over Messy Cats
DOC.TEXT: A man accused of strangling his 70-year-old neighbor Sunday reportedly killed the woman after flying into a rage because she refused to clean up after some stray cats she fed. Masaru Himuro, 60, turned himself in to police after using a small bath towel to strangle Shinobu Izu, early Sunday morning, said a police official in Fukuoka, a city on the southwestern island of Kyushu. He gave no other details. However, Kyodo News Service reported that Himuro began drinking after losing money while gambling Saturday evening. It said he went to Izu's apartment to complain she had not cleaned up the excrement of five or six stray cats she often fed. The report said Izu refused to apologize, and Himuro killed her in a rage, it said.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Actor Robert Duvall has prepared himself for roles by hanging out with bums on the Bowery, riding horses with the Texas Rangers and tramping through a Louisiana swamp with an alligator hunter. He's not sure if it was all worth it. ``You could do all the research in the world _ sometimes it pays off, sometimes it doesn't,'' Duvall says in the March issue of Smart magazine. ``Sometimes you don't have time. You got to be a human being up there. That's the most important thing.'' Duvall, who won an Oscar for ``Tender Mercies'' and starred in ``The Godfather'' and ``The Great Santini,'' says he's a stickler for detail in his characters and in films in general. ``When actors start acting bigger than life, bigger than the people they play, then they're in trouble,'' Duvall said. ``For example, I can't even talk about `Gone With the Wind.' You don't see people in the South like that. It's a joke.''

Two queens, Elizabeth II and Beatrix, are Europe's wealthiest women, although the English monarch with an estimated personal fortune of $8.9 billion far outranks her Dutch counterpart, a magazine said Sunday. Britian's Queen Elizabeth is the fourth richest person and the richest woman in the world, reported Harpers and Queen magazine. She has a jewelery collection including 25 crowns and tiaras, racing horses, a valuable art collection and thousands of acres of land and mineral rights worldwide. Queen Beatrix of the Netherlands weighed in at an estimated $4.7 billion. Johanna Quandt, who owns 66 percent of the West German automotive company BMW, is Europe's third richest woman, the magazine said. It estimated Ms. Quandt's fortune at $3.5 billion. Another German, Grete Schickedanz, owner of Quelle, Europe's largest mail order company, is Europe's fourth wealthiest woman at $2 billion, the magazine said. Athina Roussel, the 5-year-old daughter of the late shipping heiress Christina Onassis and French pharmaceutical heir Thierry Roussel, is No. 7 on the list, although Harpers and Queen said she will not take control of her $840 million fortune until her 18th birthday, in 2003. Forbes' list of the world's richest people published in October listed Japan's Yoshiaki Tsutsumi, who made his money in land, railroads and resorts, as the world's richest individual worth about $15 billion. The Sultan of Brunei and King Fahd of Saudi Arabia have been reported by Fortune magazine to have more money at their personal disposal because of the oil riches of their countries. Estimates of the sultan's wealth have ranged up to $30 billion and Fahd's is said to be in the $18 billion range.

Comedian Milton Berle is selling his longtime home here because it contains too many memories of his late wife. ``I didn't have to sell the house,'' Berle said. ``But there are too many memories there, you know, after being married 36 years.'' The 81-year-old comic is negotiating to lease a penthouse on Wilshire Boulevard in Los Angeles for $12,000 a month. The house sold for more than $3 million cash to the owners of a mortgage company. The 60-year-old home went on the block in October following the death of Berle's wife, Ruth, in April. They had lived in the house for 19 years. Berle had asked $3.65 million, but apparently the property needs work. ``It has a lot of character but needs updating, and that's what the buyers plan to do,'' said Yaffa Lerner, who sold the house.

Pulitzer Prize winning author James Michener has bought a summer home in Brunswick, and plans to move there late this spring, a real estate broker says. ``He wanted to have access to a college library for research and where it would be cool in the summer,'' said Brunswick broker Deborah Morton. Michener, who has written such books as ``Hawaii,'' ``Alaska,'' ``Caribbean'' and ``Space,'' began house hunting last fall and found a condominium unit, but the deal was not closed until Thursday, Ms. Morton said. She would not disclose the price. The 82-year-old author is known for his historical novels, which combine history, geography and cultures of different regions. While researching his books, Michener often moves to the area he is writing about.

Journalist Tony Brown told a predominantly black audience that American blacks are crippled by a self-imposed ``psychological slavery'' that keeps them from achieving success. Brown said blacks are held captive by a myth: ``If white America doesn't provide an opportunity for them, they won't have one.'' ``You are psychologically dependent on someone else,'' Brown told about 500 people at the annual fund-raising dinner of the state chapters of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People on Saturday night. Brown, host of the black affairs television series ``Tony Brown's Journal,'' said the civil rights movement has brought changes in laws that were needed to give blacks an equal footing. But it takes more than legislation to reverse a 200-year-old mind-set of inferiority that plagues many in the black community, Brown said. He urged blacks to take pride in their African identity and not wait for others to help them reach their economic and social goals. ``If we want to be equal, let's be equal,'' he said. ``We don't need anybody to give us freedom.'' Brown also writes a column that appears in 150 black newspapers, publishes a quarterly magazine, and produces documentary films.

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds of Thousands Rally Against Party Monopoly on Power
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 9th, `Trucks blocked ...' to UPDATE with duration of rally, marchers dispersing; picks up 10th pvs: According to ...
DOC.HEAD: Laserphoto MOSB1-3
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of thousands of cheering protesters filled the broad streets of the capital Sunday to demand that the Communists surrender their stranglehold on power, perhaps the biggest protest in Moscow since the Bolshevik Revolution. The huge gathering came on the eve of a party Central Committee meeting during which President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is expected to propose that other parties be allowed to compete for power, a move likely to spur an intense struggle between hard-liners and reformers. The crowd waved huge white-red-and-blue flags of pre-revolutionary Russia and held signs warning party officials to ``Remember Romania,'' where a bloody revolt last year toppled the Stalinist regime of Nicolae Ceausescu. The masses stopped next to Red Square for gigantic rally that was meant to influence the pivotal Communist Party plenary meeting that opens Monday. ``This plenum is the party's last chance,'' declared Boris N. Yeltsin, a populist Communist leader who promised to place the crowd's demands before the 251-member Central Committee. Others, harkening to the revolution that overthrew the czar in February 1917 before being swept away by Lenin eight months later, said a new revolution was under way. ``Long live the beginning of the peaceful, non-violent revolution of February 1990!'' historian Yuri Afanasiev told the cheering crowd. Some demonstrators at the head of the rally chanted ``Politburo resign!'' Others whistled in derision when they passed the Moscow city council headquarters on Gorky Street. Trucks blocked Moscow's Garden Ring Road for the marchers who linked arms next to Gorky Park and completely filled eight lanes of traffic, stretching back more than half a mile. Cordons of uniformed police blocked cars elsewhere, turning the center of Moscow into a virtual pedestrian mall. In all, the march and rally lasted for about five hours before participants began to disperse. Police observed the peaceful proceedings in the historic heart of the capital, but there were no reports of any disturbances. According to published reports, party leader Gorbachev will propose to the Central Committee that the party give up the guarantee of power that was written into the Soviet Constitution in 1977. The Radio Moscow news service Interfax also said Gorbachev was planning structural reforms that would reduce the size of the Central Committee and possibly eliminate the ruling Politburo. He also was expected to give tacit approval to the concept of private property. The proposals are in the form of a draft platform to be placed before a congress, theoretically the Communist Party's highest body, that now is scheduled for this fall. Many Moscow observers expected a concentrated effort from conservatives in the Central Committee to stop the reforms they believe have brought the Soviet Union to economic ruin and ethnic strife. At least some in the crowd had doubts whether Gorbachev is committed to radical reforms. ``Mikhail Sergeyevich, whom are you with?'' one sign asked. Yeltsin and other reformers, speaking to the crowd gathered in front of the Moscow Hotel from the back of a blue flat-bed truck, demanded that the party and government talk with them about the Soviet Union's future, as Communist leaders have been forced to do as changes have swept the former Soviet satellites of Eastern Europe. They also urged a day of similar rallies throughout the country on Feb. 25. Yeltsin demanded that the party congress be held earlier, in May or June. The rally united reformers from the People's Front organizations of Moscow and Russia, the Association of Moscow Voters, the Memorial group dedicated to remembering the victims of Stalin, and other reformers. It marked another step in a rapid solidification of the reformers' movement. They first came together two weeks ago to form a group calling itself the Democratic Platform. ``We don't have any more time,'' said Nikolai I. Travkin, a member of the Congress of People's Deputies. ``We don't have time for disagreements among ourselves.'' Reformers say they have been scared in recent weeks by the Soviet military assault on Baku, the capital of the Azerbaijan republic where a fierce nationalist movement has taken hold; and threats of attacks on Jews by Russian nationalists. ``We are for freedom, but not the freedom of fascists! We're for freedom, but not the freedom of murderers!'' popular poet Yevgeny Yevtushenko declared. Democratic Platform formally demanded removal of the Communists' constitutional guarantee on power and a virtual apology for decades of repression and mismanagement. Some of its leaders such as Afanasiev say they are on the verge of declaring the party incapable of reform, quitting it, and forming a social democratic party. Small, local parties are forming in the Baltic republics, where legislators already have acted to remove the Communist Party's monopoly on power, but so far there is no nationwide opposition to Communist authority. Gorbachev said in the Baltic republic of Lithuania last month that it would be ``no tragedy'' if a multi-party system evolved. But he continues to insist that it is not a simple solution to all the country's problems. But reform-minded economist Gavriil Popov, also a deputy, told the crowd that the Communist Party leadership was hindering reform. ``We need a free society, with a free economy ... a society of free people,'' he said. The Soviet Union, ruled exclusively by the Communists since a few months after the 1917 Russian Revolution, is the last remaining Warsaw Pact nation to give the Communists a guaranteed monopoly on power. The two-daty Central Committee meeting is likely to be the last one before elections to governing councils in the 15 Soviet republics and cities and towns, most of which are scheduled to take place in the next month and a half. Top local party officials suffered embarrassing defeats in many cities in national elections in March, and others could lose heavily in the local elections.

DOC.HEAD: Communist Party Decides on Cautious Liberalization
With AM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Albania's hard-line Communist Party Central Committee plans to introduce some reforms as part of a cautious move away from total control of society, Albania's state ATA news agency reported Sunday. The committee at a meeting Jan. 22-23 reaffirmed its claim to power but agreed to give state enterprises more decision-making authority, permit dual candidacies for some posts and tie wages more closely to production, ATA said. Such tentative moves toward democracy cannot be compared to the whirlwind of reforms that have swept Communist parties from decades of rule in some East European countries and forced radical changes on others in the past few months. But they are relatively major developments in the context of Albania, a closed society and the most conservative European Communist nation for decades. Albania broke with the Soviet Union in 1961 over Moscow's policy of de-Stalinization and with China in 1978 because of Beijing's perceived deviation from Marxist-Leninist tenets. The ATA report added substance to reports of some shortages this winter, saying the Central Committee session agreed that ``nothing can justify the shortage of vegetables, milk and meat in every city.'' The dispatch follows unconfirmed rumors in Yugoslavia and Greece of unrest in the Albanian city of Shkoder Jan. 11 and Jan 14, with thousands of people reportedly trying to tear down a statue of Josef Stalin, the late Soviet dictator. Albanian officials denied the reports.
