The Central Committee resolutions, as reported by ATA, included: _Opening up election to seats in Parliament to more than one Communist-approved candidate. _Placing limits on the length of office for some party and government posts. _Extending economic and financial planning ``from the center to the districts and from the districts to the enterprises, cooperatives and institutions.'' _Placing more emphasis on profitablity of state enterprises. _Increasing the role of the ``collective garden, small herds and plots ... in supplying the peasantry. ... Agricultural cooperatives ... can sell agricultural and livestock products at prices set by themselves, different from the state.'' The plenum condemned ``the counter-revolutionary process'' in the Soviet bloc, saying it resulted from ``the instigation and inteference of Western reaction and of the Soviet Union.'' At the same time it acknowledged popular support for the changes, which it blamed on disillusionment with ``revisionist domination, its bureaucracy and violence.'' Albanian leaders repeatedly have emphasized that the changes sweeping Eastern Europe will not affect their country, stressing that Albania has developed separately from the Warsaw Pact for the last 40 years.

DOC.HEAD: America's Cup Dispute In New York's Top Court
DOC.TEXT: The America's Cup, the most valued prize in yachting, sits in a most unusual trophy case these days: A vault at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Co. in New York City. It's there because of a legal fight that centers on sportsmanship, fairness, history and money. New York's highest court will decide in the coming weeks whether the 139-year-old silver trophy goes to the San Diego Yacht Club or to the Mercury Bay Yacht Club of New Zealand. Mercury Bay contends the San Diego club and its skipper, Dennis Conner, cheated by using a catamaran in defeating the New Zealanders' 1988 challenge for the cup. Mercury Bay contends that Conner, using the lighter and more maneuverable catamaran, had an unfair advantage and violated the spirit of the century-old rules that established the America's Cup competition. Those rules, say the New Zealanders, require holders of the Cup to accept any challenge from any foreign country in a vessel similar to the one being used by the challenger. Mercury Bay sailed in a 132-foot fiberglass sloop and lost to Conner in two consecutive races off San Diego, described by Mercury Bay's lawyers as a ``gross mismatch.'' A catamaran had never before been used in America's Cup competition. In court papers, Mercury Bay's lawyers quote Malin Burnham, head ofthe syndicate that financed Conner's ``Stars and Stripes,'' as saying a catamaran ``would turn this race into a farce.'' The New Zealanders want Conner's victory invalidated, with the trophy awarded to them. On the other side is the San Diego Yacht Club and the America's Cup Organizing Committee, which plans to stage the next defense of the trophy. They claim that Conner's catamaran was legal and that the New Zealanders are going to court to get a prize they could not win in the water. Mercury Bay also has the backing of the New York Yacht Club, which had held the cup 132 years and 24 successful defenses, until Conner lost it to Australia in 1983. Conner, sailing for San Diego, regained the cup in 1987. The rules are contained in an 1887 document known as the ``Deed of Gift,'' which set up the America's Cup challenge system. The deed established the New York Court of Appeals as the final arbiter of America's Cup disputes. This is the first time a dispute over the cup has reached the top court. Lower state courts were divided on the issue. A trial court disqualified Conner and gave the cup to New Zealand, but an appeals court reversed that decision and awarded the cup to San Diego. The case has also generated some ill will between the two sides. Peter Debreceny, spokesman for Fay, said the New Zealanders are trying to prevent the America's Cup from becoming commercialized. He claimed Conner and San Diego wanted to hold on to the cup so they could hold a financially rewarding ``warmup'' for the America's Cup off the coast of San Diego in 1991. Officials for the America's Cup Organizing Committee deny Mercury Bay's accusation and say that they were willing to face all challengers. At stake is more than a trophy. The winner gets to host the next challenge, tentatively scheduled for 1991. That could mean an economic boost for the host community _ America's Cup matches bring spectators from around the world _ and considerable prestige for the owner of the winning yacht. About two dozen countries, including such yachting newcomers as Yugoslavia and Japan, have asked to be among the challengers in 1992. ``I think once the legalities are over, the cup will be stronger than ever,'' said Thomas Mitchell, chief spokesman for the organizing committee. ``I think everyone is keen to see it sorted out so that sportsmanship, in the end, prevails in one form or another,'' said Debreceny. A decision from the Court of Appeals could come by April. Until then, the historic silver trophy, 34 inches high and coveted by yachters worldwide, will stay in its vault on Fifth Avenue.

DOC.HEAD: American Samoa Socked by Hurricane Ofa
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING a0705 to fix category code.
DOC.TEXT: Hurricane Ofa, which packed sustained winds of 132 mph, moved away from American Samoa and Western Samoa on Sunday, leaving power outages and knocked out communications in its wake. The storm, which passed about 40 miles west of Western Samoa, was about 125 miles southwest of here at 5 a.m. HST, Richard Lay, a National Weather Service forecaster in Honolulu. Communication has been down on Western Samoa since Friday, and no information has been received on damages there. Western Samoa, a country of 160,000 people, was more in the storm's line, and damage there is expected to be severe. Territorial Gov. Peter T. Coleman, in Hawaii attending a conference, said Sunday his island was without electricity, telephone service and water. ``The situation is real bad,'' said Coleman. He spoke after getting a call from a government official on a cellular phone, the only way to communicate with the island. Injuries were minor, with 15 to 20 people being treated for cuts at American Samoa Hospital, he said. More than 200 people were evacuated Saturday from a northern coastal area of American Samoa because of dangerous high waves. Coleman said the waves were returning to normal heights Sunday and the seas were calm again, but winds remained fierce. The governor said Pago Pago Airport remained closed. High winds knocked out electrical power to about 90 percent of Tutuila, American Samoa's main island, where most of the territory's 38,000 residents live. There were also reports of minor flooding, said Maiava Hunkin, coordinator of the Territorial Emergency Management Committee.

DOC.HEAD: Details of Communist Party Central Committee
DOC.TEXT: Here is a brief look at the Communist Party Central Committee, which opens a crucial two-day session in Moscow on Monday:
DOC.HEAD: COMPOSITION:
DOC.TEXT: The Central Committee is made up of leading members of the 20 million member Soviet Communist Party, which according to the constitution is the leading and guiding force of Soviet society. In most recent years, the Central Committee has been made up of about 300 members, but last year the number was reduced to 251. Membership includes leading figures of the Soviet Communist Party from regional party organizations, the national government and party organizations, and other prominent figures from the military, arts and sciences.
DOC.HEAD: POWERS:
DOC.TEXT: The Central Committee is the policy-making body of the party. It is charged with guiding the party's work between the larger party congresses that are held every five years. Most major policy issues are brought before the Central Committee for a policy directive. Between congresses, the Central Committee alone has the power to change the composition of the Politburo, which is responsible for running the country on a day-to-day basis. It also may change the party leader.
DOC.HEAD: SELECTION:
DOC.TEXT: The Central Committee is chosen every five years by the Communist Party congress. Between congresses, members can be retired and non-voting members can be promoted to voting membership. The last congress was held four years ago. The next one is scheduled for fall.
DOC.HEAD: WHAT'S AT STAKE:
DOC.TEXT: Perhaps the future direction of the nation. This Central Committee meeting is widely expected to become an intense struggle between hard-liners who want to turn back the reforms of leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev and progressives who want to acclerate them. Gorbachev reportedly will proposed a multiparty political system, which would end the Communists exclusive claim to power for the first time in seven decades. Gorbachev also is expected to give tacit approval to the concept of private property. The meeting may represent the biggest challenge of Gorbachev's five years in power.

DOC.HEAD: Religious Services Broadcast Nationwide For the First Time Since 1940s
DOC.TEXT: State radio broadcast a regular Mass for the first time in four decades Sunday, and the official news agency said broadcasts of Protestant, Jewish and other Roman Catholic services would follow. In a separate dispatch, the official CTK news agency announced officials from the new non-Communist government would meet Kremlin officials in Moscow Wednesday for talks on withdrawing the estimated 75,000 Soviet troops from Czechoslovakia. The terse report did not specify the length of the second round of the Soviet-Czechoslovak talks or who would be participating in them. The first round in Prague Jan. 15-16 failed to provide tangible results. Archbishop Frantisek Vanak led worshipers through the Mass in the church of St. Wenceslas in the northern city of Olomouc, 180 miles east of Prague. The service was the first by Czechoslovak radio's department for religious programs, which was formed after a popular revolution ousted the country's hard-line Communist leadership and ushered in non-Communists who promised religious freedom. ``This is a continuation of a beautiful tradition, which was providing great help to those listeners who were not able to attend the services in a community of believers,'' CTK said, referring to the regular broadcasts before the 1948 Communist takeover. Plans for other live broadcasts include services from other Catholic churches, Protestant gatherings and from the Jewish synagogue in Prague, CTK said. At Lany, west of Prague, President Vaclav Havel met with the Dalai Lama and called on politicians around the world to respect truth and justice. Havel invited the Tibetan spiritual leader, winner of last year's Nobel Peace Prize, to Czechoslovakia for a private visit. The five-day trip, which began Friday, was vigorously protested by China, who said it signaled Prague's support for Tibetan separatism. The two officials made no mention of the dispute in a joint statement but called on politicians worldwide to ``act according to their conscience and the feeling of responsibility to truth and justice.'' Under Havel's government, Czechoslovakia has sought a complete withdrawal of the estimated 75,000 Soviet troops stationed in its territory by the end of the year, with at least half of them leaving by mid-May. Last week, neighboring Hungary opened negotiations with the Soviets on a Red Army withdrawal. The Soviets arrived in both countries to quash democratic movements _ the 1956 revolt in Hungary, and the 1968 ``Prague Spring'' in Czechoslovakia.

DOC.HEAD: New Information Spurs Renewed HUD Hearings by House Panel
DOC.NOTE: EDS: LEADS with 15 grafs to UPDATE with committee canceling appearance by HUD official. Picks up 12th graf pvs, bgng: `I don't
DOC.TEXT: Congressional investigators have unearthed ``additional information'' in the HUD scandal and plan to resume hearings despite Attorney General Dick Thornburgh's request for a special prosecutor, according to the chairman of the House panel. However, amid concerns about pursuing a separate investigation, the committee's chairman, Rep. Tom Lantos, D-Calif., announced Sunday he was canceling an appearance at a hearing Monday by one of the witnesses, a former top HUD official who has been cooperating with investigators. Lantos had said earlier that while he was pleased with Thornburgh's request for a prosecutor ``I disagree with him on the scope'' of the criminal investigation. ``My subcommittee will continue to do its best to develop the issue,'' Lantos said in an interview Friday. ``We have unearthed additional information, new information, and this has prompted us to continue the hearings,'' he said. He declined to say what the new evidence involved. Thornburgh asked a federal court last week to appoint a special prosecutor to investigate former Housing and Urban Development Secretary Samuel Pierce and other former top HUD officials. Thornburgh limited the request to the handling of one HUD subsidy program, however, and ruled out a request by House Judiciary Committee members that the prosecutor look at potential perjury by Pierce before the Lantos panel last spring. Lantos' committee, which conducted more than 20 hearings last year into alleged fraud, mismanagement and influence-peddling at HUD during the Reagan years, was reopening its hearings Monday. Lantos said his Government Operations subcommittee on employment and housing was scheduling more hearings too, and that he has changed his mind since last fall when he told reporters it was time to wind down the congressional probe and turn the HUD scandal over to the courts. ``We clearly will do nothing that will interfere with the work of the independent counsel,'' he said. However the committee said Sunday it was canceling the appearance of one of the scheduled witnesses, former assistant housing secretary Thomas Demery. Jerris Leonard, Demery's attorney, said Demery was prepared to testify but that he had been informed by the committee Saturday afternoon that Lantos wanted to cancel the appearance. Leonard said he was told Lantos ``wanted to discuss with the independent counsel, when he or she is appointed, the question of whether or not Mr. Demery should appear because he is at least a witness in the investigation of Mr. Pierce's activities.'' Demery could not be reached for comment Sunday, but on Friday he said creation of the special prosecutor _ known under the law as an independent counsel _ had caused him to have second thoughts about agreeing to testify before the House panel. ``I don't have a good handle on how to answer questions that are now going to be in the purview of the special prosecutor,'' said Demery, who appeared voluntarily before the panel last year and has cooperated with investigators. As a former top HUD official, Demery acknowledged, he could become an object of a special prosecutor's investigation. Also scheduled to appear was Carol Crawford, the former associate director of the Office of Management and Budget who oversaw HUD for the Reagan White House, and James Hamernick, former director of HUD's office of insured multifamily housing development. Hamernick was appearing under subpoena. His attorney, John McCahill, informed the committee he would invoke a House rule allowing subpoenaed witnesses to ban cameras and microphones when he appears, a step Pierce and other witnesses took when invoking their constitutional rights to refuse to testify on grounds of self-incrimination. Demery was expected to face questioning about his dealings with Pierce while at HUD and Pierce's decision-making process. Congressional investigators continue to be interested in Pierce's assertion during his voluntary appearance last spring that he took no direct role in contract awards, a point that was disputed in the subsequent testimony of other former HUD officials. Congressional investigators want to question Hamernick about his relationship with former Pierce executive assistant Lance Wilson. After leaving the department and becoming a housing specialist with the Wall Street firm of Paine Webber, Wilson filed expense accounts claiming he spent more than $1,000 to entertain Hamernick in a single month. Thornburgh called for an investigation of Pierce and others in the awarding of grants under HUD's section 8 moderate rehabilitation program, which provided subsidies for developers to renovate housing for low-income people. Additional witnesses, including HUD inspector general Paul Adams, are set to appear before the panel Tuesday in a hearing on alleged abuses at the Passaic, N.J., public housing authority.

DOC.HEAD: Census Bureau Hanging Out `Help Wanted' Sign
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Adds graf on how to apply for jobs
DOC.TEXT: The Census Bureau is hanging out the ``Help Wanted'' sign. People are needed across the nation to track down hard-to-count Americans and the job can pay up to $8 an hour. The census takers will scout remote hollows in West Virginia and island fishing villages in Alaska, seek out beach dwellers in California and folks living in mountain cabins in Appalachia. Only a few weeks before the official 1990 national head count, the Census Bureau says it will need 315,000 temporary workers in addition to its usual staff. Many of the temporary workers have yet to be hired, says Richard Bitzer of the bureau's field division. As in 1980, most Americans will receive a census form by mail in late March, fill it out and send it back. But officials know that for one reason or another they won't hear from several million households. Others will send in incomplete forms. It will be the job of the census enumerators to track them down by phone or in person. The peak of activity will be in April and May when 200,000 census workers will go into neighborhoods and small towns as well as across rural America to interview people. Another 115,000 workers will remain in offices tabulating information and contacting folks by phone, Bitzer said. He said a big hiring push will occur in March. New workers will have about three days of training and will work daily with their supervisors to help resolve any problems during the count. A census taker's life can be anything but boring. Over the years, the temporary workers have encountered births, family fights and more than a few other unusual cases, according to records kept by the Bureau. For example: _A census taker was helping jail inmates fill out forms when the guard was changed. Unable to convince the new shift that he didn't belong there, the man stayed behind bars for several hours until the warden confirmed his identity. _A feeble voice from behind a closed door once asked a census employee to crawl in a window. She did, and found an 85-year-old man lying helplessly on the floor. He motioned her to the next room, saying: ``My census form is in there. It's all filled out.'' She helped him into bed and called a doctor. _A worker once conducted an truly ``in depth'' interview, with a man who was trying to set a world record for being buried alive. _A farmer told a census taker he just couldn't stop plowing to be interviewed. So, each time the tractor came around the farmer was shouted a question. Two hours later the form was completed, but the census taker had a sunburn and a sore throat. For tracking down the information, the temporary census takers will earn $4.50 to $8 an hour and, when on the road, 24 cents a mile. In past years many of the workers were housewives, but that pool of workers has been declining in number and officials have increasingly had to turn elsewhere, especially to retirees. A law was enacted last year that keeps postal, federal and military retirees from losing retirement benefits if they work as census takers for less than six months. Applicants can check on the availability of local census jobs through the 484 local census offices that have been opened, and are listed under the U.S. government in telephone directories, or at state employment service offices.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney: U.S. Must Deal With Soviet Military Reality, Not Promises
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS 2 grafs after 4th graf pvs, bgng: `Intentions can,'' to include Baker's Soviet trip this week. Picks up 5th graf pvs, Congresssional leaders
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Richard Cheney said Sunday it ``makes no sense'' to cut major weapons programs despite political changes in communist countries because ``we have to deal with Soviet military capabilities and not just intentions.'' Cheney defended President Bush's proposed continued funding of the MX and Midgetman missile programs as well as the level of proposed U.S. troops cuts in Europe. Congressional critics have said the two missile programs aren't needed and more troops should be brought home. ``Intentions can change overnight ... and we have to deal with the Soviets' military capabilities and not just intentions,'' Cheney said on CBS-TV's ``Face the Nation'' program. ``There is still enormous nuclear capability'' targeted against the United States and the Soviets have provided no evidence they are prepared to change that, Cheney said. Cheney made his remarks on the eve of Secretary of State James A. Baker III's trip to Moscow this week, where he is scheduled to meet with Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev. Baker also is to meet with Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze in hopes of laying the groundwork for a possible new arms reductions treaty President Bush and Gorbachev could sign this summer. Shevardnadze also is expected to respond more formally to Bush's troop cut offer. Congressional leaders, meanwhile, suggested that deeper defense spending cuts are needed for the fiscal 1991 budget than the administration proposed last week and that the president's rollback in the U.S. military presence in Europe does not go far enough. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, called the continued spending for the MX missile program ``wasteful'' and unnecessary. ``I don't think there's any chance that the administration's proposal to fund both (the MX and Midgetman) will be enacted,'' said Mitchell on NBC-TV's ``Meet the Press.'' Last week three former chairmen of the Joint Chiefs of Staff told a congressional hearing the administration should cancel plans to modernize its land-based nuclear missile force _ including the MX and Midgetman _ if U.S. Soviet agreement is reached on a strategic weapons treaty. The Bush budget calls for $2.5 billion to place the U.S. fleet of the 10-warhead MXs on rail cars. It also calls for a $202 million for a new missile, the truck-based, single-warhead Midgetman. ``It makes no sense for us unilaterally to cut those program when there's no military rationale for doing so,'' argued Cheney, adding that the U.S. response to developments in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe should be limited to conventional weapons issues. But Cheney and White House chief of staff John Sununu rejected deeper troop cuts than the president's proposal. Bush proposed a cutting U.S. combat forces in central Europe from 255,000 troops to 195,000. Mitchell said reductions to ``somewhere in the range of 100,000'' should be pursued with the Soviets. House Speaker Tom Foley, D-Wash., also predicted U.S. troop strength would be ``something closer to 100,000 than 195,000 ... in a matter of a few years.'' ``The game is always whatever the White House lays out, they play `call and raise' on the Hill,'' Sununu said. Foley and Sununu made their remarks on ABC-TV's ``This Week with David Brinkley.'' On other matters: _ Cheney denied playing politics when assembling the list of U.S. military bases marked for closing. Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo., said 90 percent of the bases listed for closing by the Republican administration were in Democratic districts, but Cheney said he was unaware of that when the list was compiled. _ Congressional leaders agree that the competition is intense for money from any so-called peace dividend. Noting the government's huge deficit, Foley said reduced defense spending ``may get (us) closer to paying our way'' and that there are many demands in social programs that also require funds. ``For those who think the (peace) dividend will solve a lot of other problems, they've got to put it into perspective,'' said Sen. Pete Domenici, R-N.M., noting the size of the federal deficit. Domenici, the ranking Republican on the Senate Budget Committee, also appeared on the Brinkley program.

DOC.HEAD: Shotgun Fires Damages British Embassy
With AM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Assailants Sunday shot out windows at the British Embassy here, a day after right-wing graffiti was spray-painted on the building, an embassy spokesman said. There was no claim of responsibility for the shooting or the vandalism, which may have been in retaliation for Britain's endorsement of the political reforms announced Friday by President F.W. de Klerk. John Sawyer, a spokesman for the embassy, said three shots were fired at the building about 2:30 p.m. No one was injured, and the attackers fled in a vehicle, he said. Sawyer said the embassy requested and received extra police protection following the attack, and it was considering seeking extra protection at its four other diplomatic offices in South Africa. British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher was one of many Western leaders to praise de Klerk for lifting bans on militant black opposition groups and pledging to free black leader Nelson Mandela. She invited de Klerk and Mandela to visit Britain. Far-right organizations in South Africa were outraged by de Klerk's actions and vowed to mobilize resistance to the changes.

DOC.HEAD: Outgunned and Trapped, Christian General Aoun Now a Cult Figure
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to ADD offensive to crush the Lebanese Forces, EDITS to conform; pickup 11th graf pvs, `The Arabic-language...' Version moved in advance Jan. 30 as b0342.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NIC1 of Jan. 31
With AM-Lebanon, Bjt
DOC.TEXT:
Increasingly isolated in a Christian enclave, the rebel general Michel Aoun has become a cult figure. Hundreds of his loyalists have paid him homage daily at Lebanon's shell-shattered presidential palace, which he has turned into the ``home of the people.'' Children have smashed open their clay piggy banks at Aoun's feet while businessmen spill wads of banknotes from plastic bags to aid what many others see as a hopeless campaign to drive the powerful Syrian army out of Lebanon. To the Syrians and their allies, Aoun is someone whose lust for power not only blocks efforts to end Lebanon's 14-year-old civil war but could unleash more bloodshed and destroy what's left of the country. ``A clown, a clever clown,'' the Druse Moslem chieftain Walid Jumblatt called him. Prime Minister Salim Hoss, a Sunni Moslem, described him as ``nothing but a television show.'' But Aoun is a champion to the young people in the Christian enclave ringed on three sides by hostile forces and by the Mediterranean on the other. An estimated half of the 1 million Christians trapped inside the enclave support the general. Others, like the right-wing Phalangists and the Lebanese Forces militia, oppose him. Since Tuesday, Aoun has waged a savage offense in the Christian enclave to crush the Lebanese Forces but so far has failed to do so. At least 200 people have been killed and 900 wounded, mostly civilians, in the deadly fighting that has sent an estimated 500,000 people to basement bomb shelters. Before the most recent fighting, young women at the Ouragan night club in Christian east Beirut would flash V-for-Victory signs with their fingers as they danced and shout ``Aoun! Aoun!'' In other discos, youngsters sang ``General, General,'' a paean of praise for Aoun set to the tune of the Little Richard classic ``Tutti Frutti.''
The Arabic-language song ridicules rival Christian and Moslem leaders who endorsed an Arab League peace plan in Saudi Arabia last October under which Elias Hrawi was elected president of Lebanon on Nov. 24. Aoun, whose 20,000 soldiers control the enclave, rejects the accord on grounds that it does not guarantee the withdrawal of the 40,000 Syrian soldiers in Lebanon. They were deployed under a 1976 Arab League peacekeeping mandate. Aoun charges they betrayed that mandate by openly siding with the Moslems and leftists. All 45 foreign ambassadors accredited in Lebanon have shunned Aoun since Hrawi's election in November. But the general pledges to continue the ``war of liberation'' he launched in March 1989 to drive out the Syrians, even though his forces are heavily outnumbered. At least 929 people were killed and 2,744 wounded before the guns were silenced by an Arab League cease-fire Sept. 22. Hrawi, who has officially removed Aoun as Lebanon's army commander and interim prime minister, wants the presidential palace so he can rule from the symbol of state authority. Aoun refuses to recognize Hrawi as president or vacate the palace, which is mostly in ruins. Some of Aoun's supporters look upon him with a religious fervor. ``Jesus Christ is our savior in heaven and Michel Aoun is our Jesus and our savior on earth,'' a woman commented in a broadcast by Aoun's Radio Lebanon. Some Maronite Catholics even hold christenings and other church rituals in the palace courtyard, strung with lights that spell out in Arabic ``God bless our home.'' The general has come up from his bunker, two stories under the palace, almost every day to deliver a political sermon to his followers. His speeches, delivered from behind an armored shield draped with the Lebanese flag, are often interrupted by shouts of ``Syria get out'' and ``With our blood and souls we sacrifice ourselves to you, O General.'' When winter rains soak them, supporters amend the chant: ``With our flu we sacrifice ourselves to you.'' Aoun's officers exhort the crowds to shout louder above the taped cheers blaring from loudspeakers while the TV cameras roll. When it looked as if the Syrians were going to attack Baabda in October, thousands of Aoun's young loyalists formed a ``human shield'' around the palace. About 500 are still camping out in dozens of colored tents nestled among the trees around the palace. With the winter weather, the tents are mostly empty during the day. But they're crowded at weekends. ``We stay up till dawn, dancing,'' said John, who did not want his full name used because he often slips into west Beirut, the capital's Moslem sector. ``The best parties we have are the ones we hold here. ``Why shouldn't we party? We've won the battle against the Syrians,'' he added, seemingly oblivious to prospect of a possible military assault to dislodge Aoun from the palace.

DOC.HEAD: Tornadoes Pound Central Alabama; Winter Makes Comeback in Northeast
DOC.TEXT: Tornadoes pounded a wide span of central Alabama, flinging tractor-trailer rigs across a highway near Birmingham, and winter made its presence felt in the Northeast, dropping 16 inches of snow in Portland, Maine. No deaths or serious injuries were reported in the violent storms late Saturday, said Greg McWhorter, a spokesman for the Alabama Department of Emergency Management. McWhorter said 150 homes and about 15 businesses were damaged in Fultondale, north of Birmingham. There were reports of five minor injuries, he said. Brian Peters, a National Weather Service meteorologist at Birmingham, said at least four tornadoes raked the state. Peters said he surveyed the affected areas early Sunday and found damage was widespread but scattered. ``The damage was not really what would be classified as major damage,'' he said. Near Monroe, N.C., thunderstorm gusts damaged several farm buildings. Advisories for snow were posted for the mountains of Southern California and the southern Sierra Nevada. Gale warnings were issued for much of the northern Pacific Coast Sunday and the mountains of Southern California. By late Sunday morning, 16 inches of snow covered Portland, Maine; 12 inches at Concord N.H. and Syracuse N.Y.; 10 inches at Montpelier, Vt.; 9 inches at Bangor, Maine; and 4 to 8 inches over the western Finger Lakes. Overnight snowfalls reached as much as 7 inches across southwest Illinois, and by midmorning there were reports of up to 7 inches of new snow across the southern Sierra Nevada and the Tehachapi Mountains of California. Snow was falling Sunday afternoon over much of New England, except along the coastline, across New York state and into northern and western Pennsylvania; rain extended across the New England coast, southeast New York state, New Jersey, and parts of Pennsylvania, Maryland, Delaware and Virginia. Showers and occasional thunderstorms pelted the central sections of the Carolinas, while snow fell in the panhandle and central part of Idaho. Rain hit southwest California, with rain mixing with snow or changing to snow in the higher elevations. The low temperature for Lower 48 states was 15 degrees below zero at both Caribou and Houlton, Maine. Some cities set record highs for the date, including the place dubbed ``The Nation's Icebox'' _ International Falls, Minn., which had a 46-degree reading, 5 degrees higher than the 1968 mark. Cape Hatteras, N.C., reached 71 degrees, breaking the 69-degree record set in 1932. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 1 degree below zero at Houlton to 87 degrees at Melbourne, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: Bright and Brief
DOC.TEXT: Zoo officials want to give Mac the bison a home where the buffalo roam. Mac, who weighs 1,800 pounds, currently resides in Lansing's Fenner Arboretum, but Potter Park Zoo officials want to move him somewhere where he can live with other animals. ``That animal's not in a good setting,'' said zoo Director Douglas Finley. ``It's alone. It should be with other bison.'' This saddens Wes Goins, who lives next door to the arboretum and who made friends with the big beast by feeding him apples until Mac finally ate out of his hand. The zoo feeds Mac grass, hay and grain but Goins regularly treats him to corn and fruit. Zoo officials discourage the extra feedings. ``He eats apples, grapes, bananas, plums. ... I know he likes kiwi,'' Goins said. ``He's a fruit freak.'' Goins said Mac eats bananas peel and all, but prefers his apples sliced, his oranges peeled and his peaches pitted. Mac once shared the pasture with antelope, longhorn cattle, deer and prairie dogs, which have since died or been relocated. Mac sired several calves with a bison cow, but she died three years ago. Goins said he'll visit Mac wherever he goes if they are separated. ``I think if they took him out of here and I went to see him, I think he'd come if I called him,'' he said. City officials will move Mac to a new home if the Friends of the Arboretum decide that living among other bison would be best for him.

The newly arrived traveler from South Korea waited in vain at Dulles International Airport near Washington, D.C., for a friend to pick him up. There was a good reason. ``His ride was in Dallas,'' explained Mary Villalobos, manager of the foreign-traveler greeting service at the suburban Virginia airport. ``When they hear `Dulles,' they think Texas. It happens all the time.'' Lisa Smith, director of the Washington Airports Task Force, said the names typically confuse visitors from the Middle East and Far East. ``If they're not enunciated clearly, it's hard to tell the difference,'' she said. Such confusion may be about to end, thanks to a move to rename the capital's principal international airport in honor of the late President Eisenhower, whose 100th birthday will be celebrated in October. Sen. Bob Dole, R-Kan., introduced the resolution last week urging the Metropolitan Washington Airports Authority to rename the airport, which bears the name of Eisenhower's longtime secretary of state, John Foster Dulles. Nearly all of the authority board's 11 members support Dole's proposal, according to board member Michael Barnes. ``My hope is that the name will be changed by October 14, Eisenhower's birthday,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Gunmen Assassinate a Mayor and a Journalist as Army Finds Drug Money
DOC.TEXT: Unidentified gunmen assassinated a mayor and a journalist and shot at a congressman in separate incidents over the weekend, authorities said Sunday. The mayor's body was left draped in a flag of leftist guerrillas, who have promised a wave of violence leading up to mayoral and congressional elections early next month. Also Sunday, the army said it discovered more than $2.4 million in cash on a ranch once owned by Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, the Medellin cartel leader killed in a Dec. 15 gunfight with police. The money, found Saturday, had been buried on the banks of the Magdalena River near the town of Guaduas, 43 miles north of Bogota. Soldiers searching the ranch also found more than 100 weapons, an army communique said. Last November, the army found $5.2 million in cash buried at another ranch belonging to Rodriguez Gacha, considered the most violent of the Medellin cartel leaders. A Sunday communique from the Norte de Santander state government office said the mayor of the town of Arboledas, Pedro Jesus Hernandez, was shot and killed by several gunmen who covered his body with a flag bearing the initials ELN. The letters stand for the National Liberation Army, the country's most active leftist guerrilla group. Led by a defrocked Catholic priest, the ELN has been blamed for the assassinations of three mayors in the past 35 days. The group has pledged to carry out a campaign of attacks, kidnappings and assassinations in northeastern Colombia to disrupt congressional and mayoral elections scheduled for March 11 and presidential balloting to be held May 27. Hernandez, a member of the opposition Conservative Party, had been traveling in a car late Saturday on his way to inaugurate a cafeteria for poor children when the attackers opened fire, the government communique said. Arboledas is a town of 15,000 people 217 miles northeast of Bogota. In Puerto Asis, 322 miles south of the capital, assailants also suspected of being leftist guerrillas opened fire Saturday on a Conservative Party congressman, Ernesto Muriel. He escaped the attack uninjured, the national police said in a communique. In the river port of Barrancabermeja, two men traveling on a motorcycle gunned down a journalist, Cayetano Dominguez, in front of the offices of Caracol radio network, where he worked, a national police communique said. Police said they were trying to determine the motive for the Friday night assassination. Since 1977, more than 45 journalists have been killed in Colombia, the majority of them by drug traffickers. The government declared war on the traffickers in August and began extraditing suspects to the United States to face drug-related chargeds. The cocaine lords responded with a terror campaign that has killed 209 people and included the bombing of a Colombian airliner.

DOC.HEAD: Banks, Other Lenders Seek To Reduce Loan Defaults
DOC.NOTE: For Release at 6:30 p.m. EST, time set by source
DOC.TEXT: Using aggressive tactics that included garnishing lottery winnings and putting liens on real estate, banks and other lenders in three years doubled the money recovered from delinquent student loan borrowers, a study showed Sunday. Lenders in the Guaranteed Student Loan Program, which has made higher education possible for more than 20 million Americans since created by Congress in 1965, ``introduced innovative procedures to forestall default'' and increase recoveries from $200 million in fiscal year 1986 to more than $400 million in fiscal year 1989. ``The very magnitude of this program ... has created an urgent concern to prevent defaults and increase collections from borrowers who have run into trouble,'' said Pelavin Associates, a Washington, D.C. research firm that conducted three national studies on the GSL program for a consortium of guarantee agencies in Colorado, Massachusetts, Tennessee, Texas and Washington state. Government student loan programs have been harshly criticized in recent years because of spiralling huge default rates, mainly among trade and vocational schools. The GSL program, which is administered by 56 guarantee agencies that protect private lenders against losses from loan defaults, had $51.6 billion in student loans entering repayment status in fiscal year 1988. The federal government is the ultimate guarantor of the loans. Last year, the Education Department announced it would try to collect more than 100,000 defaulted student loans, worth more than $300 million. These include loans that were made to borrowers who have never made a payment on their student loans and also loans to students who have not made a payment in the five years following their loan default. According to the new studies, eighteen guarantee agencies improved their recovery rates by more than 10 percent and 22 agencies saw improvements between 5 percent and 10 percent. Half the agencies took problem borrowers to court, while 20 states got tough by withholding defaulters' state income tax refunds. Eighteen states used outside collection agencies to supplement their own resources. Colorado garnished wages. Utah put liens on real estate. Texas and Illinois did not renew professional licenses for doctors, nurses, lawyers and beauticians until their debts were resolved. California garnished lottery winnings for a few defaulters lucky enough to win money. A study on loan default reductions found that 48 out of 56 guarantee agencies have reduced the percentage of loans in default since 1986. The federal government rewards low default rates by tying reimbursement allocations to an annual performance calculation known as the ``Trigger Rate.'' Twenty-nine of the guarantee agencies qualified for full reimbursement. In other findings: _Fourteen guarantee agencies used special procedures to disqualify troublesome proprietary schools during the past four years. Texas, Georgia and Oklahoma limited the number of loans problem schools could process. Eleven states suspended proprietary schools, and six states terminated schools permanently from the guaranteed loan program. _Four actions were instituted against lenders. Lender violations included failure to follow administrative procedures, inaccurate records, and incorrect federal reporting.

DOC.HEAD: Jesse Jackson Hopeful and Cautious About South African Govt's Reform
With AM-South Africa, Bjt
LaserPhoto LON3
DOC.TEXT: By GRAHAM HEATHCOTE=

Jesse Jackson said Sunday that South Africa will not be accepted internationally until the white-led government of President F.W. de Klerk abolishes apartheid. ``De Klerk cannot stop now,'' the U.S. civil rights leader said in a sermon at St. James's Anglican church in Piccadilly, London. ``De Klerk must continue beyond to bring about a democratic, open, non-racial society in South Africa.'' De Klerk announced Friday that black leader Nelson Mandela will be freed from prison soon. He also legalized Mandela's African National Congress guerrilla movement and eased emergency regulations. After preaching at St. James's, a fashionable church and a center for left-wing causes, Jackson addressed a cheering rally of about 1,200 people in London's rundown Hackney district. He is in London on a three-day stopover on his way to visit South Africa for the first time since 1979. He is due to have talks with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher on Monday. Jackson told the church congregation there was hope for the future in de Klerk's speech. But, he added: ``The caution is that the structures of apartheid are still in place.'' A mainly black crowd filled Hackney's Empire Theater three hours before Jackson arrived. ``We don't go to South Africa as tourists or visitors but as brothers and sisters going home,'' Jackson told them. ``We have been separated for so long in the diaspora. Africans everywhere, in Britain, the Caribbean, the United States and Africa, are members of one family with an obligation to stand together to make the world better,'' he said. Diane Abbott, the first black woman elected to the British House of Commons, told the rally that it was pressure from South Africa's black majority that won Mandela's freedom. ``No one has freed black South Africans _ they freed themselves.'' Jackson is to meet with President Kenneth Kaunda of Zambia on Tuesday and arrive in South Africa on Wednesday. The South African visit was arranged before de Klerk's actions Friday. Jackson was invited by Walter Sisulu, an ANC leader freed last year after spending more than 20 years in jail with Mandela, and the South African Council of Churches.

DOC.HEAD: White House Event to be Broadcast Feb. 14
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and his wife Barbara hosted their third ``In Performance at the White House'' concert Sunday. The concert was taped for broadcast Feb. 14 by the Public Broadcasting Service. It featured opera diva Marilyn Horne, singer-actress Patti LuPone, singer Jeffrey Osmond, country singer Gary Morris and the Dick Hyman Trio. The theme of the concert was ``A Presidents' Day Party.'' The earlier concerts were aired around the 4th of July and Columbus Day.

DOC.HEAD: Bradley's Political Mentor Disputes Allegations He Misused Poverty Funds
DOC.TEXT: A political mentor to Mayor Tom Bradley disputed allegations Sunday that he used $336,000 in federal poverty funds to renovate a dilapidated building he secretly owned. The City Council granted loans to Bishop H. Hartford Brookins, who owned the building through a non-existent corporation, between 1982 and 1985, in apparent violation of city bidding procedures and despite his refusal sometimes to provide financial information, the Los Angeles Times reported in Sunday editions. In addition, a Bradley aide repeatedly asked two city administrators to grant special help to the bishop, city officials said. In a telephone interview from Virginia published Sunday in the Times, Brookins said the office complex initially was acquired by an arm of the African Methodist Episcopal Church. ``The property was in the name of the Southern California Conference AME Church,'' Brookins said. ``It does exist. Whether it is incorporated, I don't know.'' Brookins said he will pay back the city any money he may owe. But he insisted he has done nothing improper. ``I know everything was done aboveboard and signed off by the city,'' Brookins said. ``That's why I'm not shaking in my boots right now.'' Los Angeles City Council members said they will conduct an inquiry this week into city loans used to renovate the office complex to see if public funds were misused. ``My basic question is what's going on? How come we didn't know about it earlier?'' Councilman Robert Farrell said. Brookins, former AME bishop in Los Angeles and now head of the church in Virginia, Maryland, and Washington, D.C., acknowledged that he now owns the office complex. He said the African Methodist Episcopal Church can have it back by paying him about $900,000 that he owes on the property. Brookins received the loans through the city's Community Development Department to renovate a run-down building complex for a jobs and education program. Later, the city program was shifted to a dilapidated office next door while the refurbished building was leased for $10,000 per month. The complex was refinanced to net the bishop $250,000. Bradley has refused to be interviewed about Brookins, but Deputy Mayor Mark Fabiani said that Bradley is concerned about the allegations. Brookins headed Bradley's first campaign for City Council in 1963 and has been chairman or co-chairman of every Bradley campaign since. ``I mean literally, if I may, I almost hand-carried Bradley up his whole political career,'' Brookins said in a 1985 interview.

DOC.HEAD: Former Italian Secret Service Head Dies at 81
DOC.TEXT: Adm. Eugenio Henke, who led the Italian secret service in the late 1960s when its agents were linked to right-wing terrorism and coup plots, died Sunday at 81, the ANSA news agency reported. Henke died of a heart attack in a military hospital in Rome, the report said. He led the secret service from 1966 to 1970 and served as military chief of staff from 1972 to 1975. Henke was called as a witness in a number of parliamentary and judicial investigations and always denied knowledge of any illegal activity by his agents.

DOC.HEAD: Retired GM Board Member Dies
DOC.TEXT: Harold G. Warner, who rose from General Motors Corp. parts installer to member of the automaker's board of directors, died of cancer at his home. He was 81. Warner, who died Friday, retired in 1973 after a 46-year career with GM. ``In a career that spanned nearly half a century, Harold Warner contributed greatly to the growth of General Motors, as an engineer, an administrator and member of the board of directors,'' said GM Chairman Roger B. Smith. Warner went to work for GM in 1927, and earned his engineering degree at the General Motors Institute in Flint. He was named executive vice president in charge of the operations staff and a member of the board in 1968. Survivors include his wife, Elizabeth, and a daughter. A memorial service was scheduled for Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Protesters Picket Salvadoran President
DOC.TEXT: El Salvadoran President Alfredo Cristiani attracted dozens of protesters Sunday when he went to Harvard University, apparently to watch his son play in a squash match, officials said. Harvard spokesman Peter Costa said Cristiani was in town for ``a private, family visit.'' Costa said he was told Cristiani's son was a member of Princeton University's squash team, which was playing Harvard. Dozens of protesters opposed to El Salvadoran military policies demonstrated outside the Harvard gymnasium, banging pots and pans. Earlier in the day, protesters gathered outside the Cambridge hotel where Cristiani was staying. The demonstrators brought letters from Cambridge Mayor Alice Wolf and from the Cambridge, Belmont and Arlington sister city projects. The letters described how recent delegations that visited sister cities in El Salvador reported continuing human rights abuses by the military. In her letter, Wolf said children often have been the victims of military raids in Cambridge's sister city of San Jose Las Flores. ``Our president, George Bush, frequently justifies the military aid that our country sends your government on the grounds that you have at long last brought the armed forces of El Salvador under democratic civilian control,'' the letter said. ``Judging from their behavior towards San Jose Las Flores, this does not seem to be the case.''

DOC.HEAD: Italian Killed, Three Injured in Avalanche
DOC.TEXT: One Italian was killed and three were injured in a major avalanche that struck Sunday in a Swiss Alps area frequented by skiers roaming outside prepared runs, officials said. Grisons state police identified the victim as Antonio Ghisetti, 37, of Crema, Italy. Police said three Italians were injured when the snowslide hit at about 6,600 feet on the Piz Uccello peak in the southeastern state. At the time, more than 80 people were skiing outside prepared runs in the area above the village of Mesocco, east of the San Bernardino Pass, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Police Restrict Drug Arrests
DOC.TEXT: The Police Department has quotas limiting the number of drug arrests by individual officers to save overtime pay, the Daily News reported Sunday. The News said narcotics officers are ordered to stop making arrests for the rest of the month when they reach the unofficial 35-hour overtime limit, which amounts to about three arrests. Police Commissioner Lee Brown denied the report. ``We do not stop making arrests at any point in time because of overtime,'' Brown said. ``A guy can reach his 35 hours in the first week or two, then sit around the rest of the month and do nothing,'' the News quoted an unidentified narcotics officer as saying. ``I've been told in a month when I had great felony arrests that I was going to be put on the telephone because I'm making too many'' arrests, said another. Brown, however, said department policy merely ``supervises the distribution of the overtime. It would not be correct if one officer received all the overtime and another officer did not receive any. ``So it's just a matter of management, to insure that there is an equal work load.''

DOC.HEAD: Print Shop Owner Interviewed In Mail Bomb Probe Attended NAACP Meetings
DOC.TEXT: The white print shop owner whose property was searched by the FBI in its mail bomb investigation has belonged to the NAACP's local chapter for three years, the chapter's president said Sunday. But the attorney for Brian Joseph Fleming, 32, said that membership was not the reason his client's print shop and home were searched Friday. Lawyer John Knowles said the searches were probably related to Fleming's indictment on charges of conspiring to export weapons, reportedly to Northern Ireland. There have been no arrests in the investigation of December mail bombings that killed 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals Judge Robert Vance and Savannah, Ga., lawyer Robert Robinson. Two other bombs were intercepted at the Jacksonville, Fla., NAACP office and the 11th Circuit courthouse at Atlanta. The threat to the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People aroused fears that all the bombings were racially motivated. That concern was heightened by a letter from an obscure group claiming responsibility for them. Fleming, who has come under the scrutiny of FBI agents probing the mail bombs, has pleaded innocent to an unrelated federal conspiracy charge and remains free on $50,000 bond. Knowles said Sunday he didn't know of Fleming's NAACP connection and refused to allow his client to be interviewed. In Enterprise, Z.I. Fleming Sr., president of the Coffee County NAACP, said the print shop owner paid the $10 annual dues and joined the local chapter in 1987. ``I know him pretty well. He appeared to me to be interested in our goals,'' said Fleming, who is black. B.F. Garth, another NAACP member, said he saw the print shop owner during meetings and doubted that Fleming was trying to infiltrate the chapter. ``He participated in discussions and acted like an ordinary member to me,'' Garth said. On Friday, Fleming and his wife, Georgia, were fingerprinted during separate trips to the police station while the searches were under way. The attention focused on Fleming, who has not been charged in the mail bomb case, drew the spotlight away from Robert Wayne O'Ferrell, the salvage store operator whose 11th Circuit appeal in an employment compensation case attracted the FBI's attention.

DOC.HEAD: Communist Party Changes Name, Promiss To Hand Over Millions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to RECAST and CORRECT figure to $600 million sted $600,000, ADDS detail. Pickup 6th graf pvs, `The moves...'; INSERTS 2 grafs after 14th graf pvs, `Modrow said...' to UPDATE with NATO chief's comment on reunification. Pickup 15th graf pvs, `Since East...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's Communist Party on Sunday changed its name and promised to hand over $600 million in assets to the government in an apparent attempt to improve its image ahead of coming elections. Also Sunday, West Germany's foreign minister promised to seek immediate financial aid to stabilize East Germany's economy while it adopts democratic reforms that could lead to reunification. Hans-Dietrich Genscher, who was born near Halle in what is now East Germany, also told a political rally in East Berlin that European neighbors have nothing to fear from a united Germany. In pursuit of unification, Bonn appears willing to swear off future claims to ethnic German regions that are now part of Poland, Czechoslovakia and the Soviet Union. Leaders of East Germany's disgraced Communist Party met and formally changed its name to the Party of Democratic Socialism. It previously had been known as the Socialist Unity Party of Germany. The party also said it will hand over $600 million from its private reserves to government coffers because the ``country's economic situation requires such support,'' the government news agency ADN reported. ADN said the money came from party dues and party-owned businesses such as printing operations. It did not say what the party's total reserves are. The moves were the latest attempt by the Communists to shore up their image ahead of the March 18 elections. The first free balloting in the nation's 40-year history was made possible by a pro-democracy revolution last year that ousted hard-line Communist Party chief Erich Honecker on Oct. 18. The Communists, who dominate the current interim government headed by Premier Hans Modrow, are widely blamed for the nation's economic problems. Genscher, noting the dire state of the East German economy, said Bonn will have to help its struggling neighbor provide health care and basic goods and services for its increasingly restive citizens. ``German unity will not come for free,'' Genscher told a founding congress of the opposition East German Free Democratic Party. West Germany also is considering other measures to help East Germany. West German Finance Minister Theo Waigel proposed last week that the West German mark be introduced as the recognized currency in East Germany to give its 16 million citizens confidence that reforms are imminent. A prominent East German politician, Dresden Mayor Wolfgang Berghofer, also appealed for immediate currency reform during a weekend international economics conference in the Swiss resort of Davos. Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany and Modrow met at Davos to discuss ways that Bonn can aid East Germany until a new government can be seated and a plan for reunification drafted. Modrow said Sunday that his own proposals for German unification are not dead despite Bonn's rejection of his position that a united Germany should be neutral. He said his neutrality proposal was only part of an effort to ``open a dialogue'' on Germany's future. In Munich, West Germany, NATO General Secretary Manfred Woerner said the Western alliance supports German unity but not at the cost of the alliance. Those who call for dissolving the Western alliance risk the ``security and unity'' of Germany and Europe, Woerner, a West German, told an annual conference of lawmakers, security experts and government officials from the NATO countries. Since East Germany ousted Honecker, opened the Berlin Wall and lifted travel restrictions, thousands of people have fled to the West each day as their nation becomes increasingly unstable. The departures, averaging 2,000 a day in January, are reducing the nation's productivity and causing food shortages and reductions in other services. Genscher and the leader of his Free Democratic Party, Otto Graf Lambsdorff, flew to Berlin to attend the inaugural meeting of the opposition East German Free Democratic Party and to offer political support. West German politicians also plan to meet next week with other reformist political parties in East Germany. Lambsdorff urged them to band together to improve their chances of winning parliamentary seats in the March 18 voting.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Opens Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar opened at 145.59 yen on the Tokyo foreign exchange market Monday, up from Friday's close of 144.95 yen.

DOC.HEAD: Moslem Militants Renew Attacks With Bombings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with suspected Sikh militants killing nine people; pickup 4th graf pvs, `The attacks...'
DOC.TEXT: Moslem separatists on Sunday blew up a bus and hurled bombs at an Indian paramilitary patrol, a government building and the home of a state lawmaker in a new series of attacks in Kashmir's largest city. No one was killed in the attacks, the latest violence since India launched a crackdown Jan. 20 on the groups that want the northern region bordering Moslem Pakistan to secede from predominantly Hindu India. At least 76 people have died since then. Also Sunday, police said suspected Sikh militants killed nine people over the weekend in attacks on two buses in the northern state of Punjab. Sikh extremists are fighting to make an independent nation out of the rich farming state, which borders Pakistan farther south. Political leaders in Pakistan demanded that India end the crackdown in Kashmir and declared Monday a national holiday to show support for the Moslem militants. The attacks in Srinagar came Sunday morning, after authorities lifted a curfew for 12 hours. One woman was injured when a bomb exploded on an empty bus as passengers were gathering to board, witnesses and a police said. The bomb destroyed the vehicle and damaged three nearby shops. Members of the Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front, also speaking on condition of anonymity, said their group was responsible for the attacks, which included bombs thrown at a paramiliary patrol, at a government office, the home of a state legislator, and a school. There were no further reports of injuries. Shops on Sunday stayed shut, respecting a strike call by the Islamic militant. Srinagar, a city of 1 million, is the summer capital of Jammu-Kashmir state, which has been claimed by both India and Moslem Pakistan since the two nations were partitioned along religious lines upon attaining independence from Britain in 1947. The two traditionally hostile neighbors went to war in 1948 and 1965 over the territory. India has repeatedly charged Pakistan with fomenting the trouble on its side of the cease-fire line, a charge routinely dismissed by Pakistan. In the Pakistani capital of Islamabad, the demand for an end to the Indian crackdown came in a rare agreement between governing and opposition parties. Pakistan's combined opposition of right-wing, centrist and religious parties called for a nationwide strike on Monday in support of the separatists. Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's government replied by declaring Monday a holiday in a show of solidarity with them. Jammu-Kashmir is the only Indian state with a Moslem majority. It is composed of the predominantly Hindu southern Jammu region and the mostly Moslem northern Kashmir sector. A western section of Kashmir is controlled by Pakistan along a cease-fire line where Indian and Pakistani troops face each other, sometimes at distances of only a few hundred yards. Nationally, Hindus comprise 82 percent of India's 880 million people, but they make up only 32 percent of Jammu-Kashmir's 5 million people.

DOC.HEAD: Five Children, Man Killed in Fiery Accident
DOC.TEXT: Five children and a 20-year-old man were killed Sunday when the vehicle they were in skidded on a patch of ice on an interstate, overturned and burst into flames, a state trooper said. The accident happened around 7:30 a.m. as the four-wheel-drive vehicle was heading west on Interstate 44 near this southwest Missouri town, according to Highway Patrol Trooper Leslie Crowe. The driver, Howard Bouchard, 38, of Denton, Texas, escaped by kicking out a window, and pulled the children's mother from the front seat of the burning vehicle, but passersby held him back when he tried to rescue the others, Crowe said. The trooper identified the dead as Edna England, 16; Clara England, 14; Ella England, 12; Virginia England, 11; and Virgil England, 10, all of Denton; and Arthur Brown, 20, of Watertown, N.Y. The children's mother, Marcella England, 38, and Bouchard were treated for minor burns at a hospital in Springfield and released.

DOC.HEAD: Israelis Say Attack Planned, Carried Out At A Sensitive Moment
With AM-Israel-Bus Attack
DOC.TEXT: Israeli officials said Sunday the attack on a bus carrying Israeli tourists in the Egyptian desert was a carefully planned operation carried out at a sensitive moment in the Middle East peace process. In the assault, at least eight people were killed and 17 were injured when masked men fired machine guns and hurled hand grenades at the bus on a desert road about 40 miles north of Cairo, an Egyptian government statement said. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, speaking in an interview with Israel Television, said: ``This murderous attack on Israeli tourists in the center of Egypt is a most serious, shocking event. ... This attack proves that hostility towards Israel still exists and runs amok in the region.'' ``We hope the Egyptian authorities will do everything possible to find the killers, punish them and prevent further events of this sort,'' Shamir said. The attack came two days before a crucial meeting of Shamir's hard-line Likud bloc, at which Shamir is to defend his Middle East peace plan against assaults by a group of influential party hawks. Shamir's plan calls for Palestinian elections in the occupied territories as a first step toward peace. The hawks say the plan, approved by Israel's coalition government, is too dangerous for the country. If Shamir is successful, a meeting of foreign ministers of the United States, Israel and Egypt is likely to take place later this month to prepare for a round of Israeli-Palestinian talks in Cairo. However, the attack could strengthen the positions of hard-liners who want to block Shamir's peace plan and say Egypt cannot be a fair mediator because of its close links with the PLO. Although Israel officially considers the PLO to be a terrorist group, Likud hard-liners fear Shamir's plan would give it a role in peace negotiations. ``We should not accept any expressions of sorrow anymore. The Egyptians have to prove they are disassociated only by one way, a total rejection of the PLO, of PLO institutions, of their meetings with (PLO leader Yasser) Arafat and terrorists in Egypt,'' Likud lawmaker Yehoshua Matza said on Israel army radio. ``They have lately allowed these groups to operate freely in Egypt and when there is a free hand and Egyptian instigation every day, we witness such terrible killings,'' he said. Other Likud officials, including some of Shamir's supporters, were more cautious about blaming Egypt, the only Arab country with which Israel has peace. ``We can say with certainty that these criminals wanted to kill Israelis, to kill the very idea of coexistence between Israelis and Arabs,'' said Deputy Foreign Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. ``This is not a spontaneous action but a planned one. Apparently it was necessary to gather intelligence and plan it,'' he said. Ehud Olmert, Likud's Cabinet Minister in charge of Arab affairs, said ``diplomatic links with Egypt are important'' but suggested Israelis should stop visiting Egypt. Olmert's suggestion was supported by several right-wing parties, such as Moledet and Tzomet. In 1985-1986, Israeli tourism to Egypt came to a virtual halt for a year following the Oct. 6, 1985, attack in which an Egyptian policeman shot dead seven Israeli tourists in the Sinai peninsula. Finance Minister Shimon Peres of the left-leaning Labor Party, Shamir's rival and coalition partner, said Israel should pursue its peace plan despite the attack. The party has warned it would leave the government if Likud's hawks block peace efforts. ``It is clear that we have to prevail over the murderers and not leave the fate of peace at the hands of terrorists and madmen,'' he said on army radio. Education Minister Yitzhak Navon, an influential Labor leader, said the attack was ``an attempt by a radical Arab group ... to disrupt our relations with Egypt, to disrupt this peace.'' The leftist Peace Now group issued a statement calling on Jews and Arabs to ``act together to stop a crazy minority ready to spill blood in order to stop the peace process.'' Left-wing Israelis planned to organize a mass pilgrimage to Cairo for a meeting with PLO members there. The action is designed to challenge an Israeli law banning unauthorized contacts with the PLO.

DOC.HEAD: Georgians to Participate in `Largest US-USSR Exchange'
DOC.TEXT: About 260 people from around Georgia will trade places with an equal number of Soviet Georgians this April in a program planned by a group that promotes international exchanges. The ``Georgia to Georgia Friendship Exchange'' sponsored by Friendship Force will be the first time residents from around the state will take part in such a program, and is a test of the feasibility of large exchanges, said Atlanta-Tbilsi Sister City Committee Chairman George Brown. Past exchanges have involved only about 25 people, Brown said. ``Friendship Force founder Wayne Smith has dreamed of doing this by the thousands,'' he said. Exchanges between the two Georgias began in 1985 when 11 Tbilisi residents visited Atlanta. The two Georgia capitals, Atlanta and Tbilisi, later formed a Sister City relationship, and since then small delegations of residents and city leaders have visited each other. Friendship Force plans to take applications and interview prospective travelers around Georgia next weekend. The 260 Americans who make the grade are to fly to Tbilisi on April 17 for a 12-day stay. An equal number of Soviet Georgians are to arrive in Atlanta on April 18 for a week in Atlanta and another week in other sections of the state. The cost for Americans is $1,295, although financial aid will be available. He said Friendship Force workers would try to match hosts and guests with similar occupations and interests so they could see how their jobs were performed in the other country. ``We hope an elementary school teacher, for example, would be placed with someone involved with elementary schools so they could attend class and observe,'' Brown said. Brown said that if the exchange goes well, Atlanta-based Friendship Force hopes to expand the program to other states with sister cities in the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Studio's Financial Documents Show `Coming to America' Hasn't Made Money
DOC.TEXT: The hit movie ``Coming to America'' has made no profit despite $350 million in worldwide ticket sales, according to financial documents released by Paramount Pictures. The documents, released to the Los Angeles Times by court order Saturday, also show that the movie's star, Eddie Murphy, and his assistants ran up $5 million in bills for food, travel, lodging and other expenses during the making of the movie. Pulitzer Prize-winning columnist Art Buchwald and producer Alain Bernheim won a lawsuit against Paramount two months ago that claimed the studio took the idea for the 1988 movie from a screen treatment by Buchwald. Paramount was ordered to pay Buchwald and Bernheim 19 percent of the movie's net profits. A financial audit is scheduled during a forthcoming phase of the trial to determine how much money Buchwald and Bernheim should receive. The records were sealed during the trial at Paramount's request, but studio officials had testified that the movie was still in the red. Part of the reason, according to the documents, is the priority system for profit sharing set out in the contracts the studio negotiates. In the case of ``Coming to America,'' the court papers show that the cost of the film's production, marketing and distribution all come out of the gross receipts, along with more than $13 million paid to Eddie Murphy Productions and the 35 percent distribution fee charged by the studio. Charges that Paramount absorbed during the making of ``Coming to America'' could become an issue in the accounting phase of the suit. Charges to production made on Murphy's behalf included: $4,920 a week for a limousine and driver kept on call around the clock, $2,200 per week paid for a special motor home for Murphy, $1,592 per week paid to the motor home's driver, $1,500 a week for a personal trainer and $650 a week for a valet. None of those expenses came out of Murphy's $8 million salary, his 15 percent share of the film's gross receipts, his own travel and hotel expenses or his $5,000-a-week living allowance.

DOC.HEAD: Reports: Activists Kill Two Palestinians, Troops Wound Three Palestinians
DOC.TEXT: Masked Palestinian activists killed two Arabs in the occupied Gaza Strip Sunday, and three Palestinians were shot and wounded by Israeli troops in stone-throwing clashes in the territory, hospital officials reported. Arab journalists in Gaza said Mahmud Abu Ghazal, 55, owner of an auto repair shop in the Maghazi refugee camp, was shot to death by an unidentified Palestinian assailant as he was opening his store Sunday morning. Hours later, assailants stabbed to death Atidal Nazir Shaat, a 20-year-old woman from the Khan Yunis refugee camp, Arab reporters and hospital officials said. Arab reports said the motives for the killings were not immediately known. Palestinian activists have slain 176 other Arabs on suspicion of being pro-Israeli collaborators during the 2-year-old uprising against Israeli rule in the occupied West Bank and the Gaza Strip. There was no immediate Israeli comment on the killings and woundings Sunday. At least 651 Palestinians have died in clashes with Israelis during the uprising, while 43 Israelis were also killed.

DOC.HEAD: Search Discovers Missing Plane; 4 Dead, Including Congressman's Children
DOC.TEXT: A small plane missing since last week was discovered Sunday in a southeastern Oklahoma pasture, and the four people aboard were dead, the Oklahoma Highway Patrol said. The plane, which carried state Rep. Bill Brewster's two children and two others, was discovered about seven miles north of Coalgate, a town of 2,000. Kecia Brewster, 16, and Kent Brewster, 13, had accompanied their father as he kicked off his campaign for the 3rd Congressional District seat. They left McAlester on Wednesday night for Ardmore. Also on the plane were Herb Pate, 32, publisher of The Madill Record, and pilot Jack Kirkpatrick, 43. Brewster and his wife, Suzie, flew in another plane to Oklahoma City. A third plane carrying campaign workers and Brewster's other daughter landed safely in Ardmore. Ralph Eddings of Coalgate said the aircraft crashed about 100 yards from his home, but he didn't hear or see anything Wednesday night. ``I didn't have no idea it has been this close until they found it,'' said Eddings, 80. The search for the plane began early Thursday, hours after the plane failed to arrive in Ardmore. Foggy weather and rain had hampered the search for much of the time, forcing searchers to cover the ground on foot, on horseback and in four-wheel-drive vehicles while airplanes and helicopters were grounded.

DOC.HEAD: Businessmen Pray For Opposition Victory, But Prepare for Sandinistas
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th pvs, `It's a ...' to RESTORE first reference to Gurdian; picks up 11th pvs, `In recent...' ^By DORALISA PILARTE
DOC.TEXT: Nicaraguan businessmen are rooting for an opposition victory in elections Feb. 25, but they're also bracing for six more years under the leftist Sandinistas. Foreign observers say the vote could go either way. But some also say that even if the Sandinistas triumph, they will have to make changes _ especially in their economic policies. If they win, the ``force of facts'' will compel the Sandinistas to reverse their policies of central economic control and state ownership of major enterprises, one Western European diplomat observed. ``I see in some (Sandinista) commanders a very strong realization that the private sector has to be strengthened ... and that the relaunching of the economy here is impossible without its natural market, which is the United States,'' said the diplomat, who like others insisted on anonymity. Virtually all businessmen are pulling for the U.S.-backed coalition of 14 parties, the National Opposition Union. The coalition advocates free enterprise and a market economy but is also promising social service improvements to woo the left. The coalition is dominated by big business but includes a wide range of ideologies, from conservatives to communists. It has promised closer relations with the United States, which imposed economic sanctions on Nicaragua shortly after the Sandinistas, with close military ties to the Cubans and Soviets, seized power in 1979. The United States also backs the Contra rebels. If the opposition wins, it says prospects are good for attracting $400 million in immediate U.S. investment to help the war-battered economy. They say most of the money would be spent in farming and related industries. Business leaders say things have to change even if the Sandinistas win. They say the Sandinistas will have to delete provisions from the Constitution like the one that says the state is in charge of ``directing and planning the national economy.'' ``It's a matter of the Sandinista Front projecting to the world that it has changed its ideology,'' said Ramiro Gurdian, who is president of the Agricultural Producers Union. In recent years, as the nation plunged deeper into crisis, the Sandinistas loosened their grip over the economy. Gone are gasoline coupons and ration cards. Gone are government inspectors who boarded buses to confiscate staples from peasants reluctant to sell produce to the state. Critics say this is still not enough. Farmers must still sell at least part of their crops to the government at a set price and purchase such things as fertilizer from the state. ``They can't keep on like that. They just can't,'' said Gurdian. ``Communism is finished. Everywhere in the world, people are turning to the free market system. It's only these gentlemen who insist on continuing to control everything.'' The Sandinistas imposed an an austerity program to reduce inflation of 33,600 percent in 1988. But inflation was 1,689 percent last year. President Daniel Ortega, who is seeking re-election, said last week that exports rose from $230 million in 1988 to $298 million last year and imports dropped from $807 million to $711 million. But Nicaragua's currency, the cordoba, had to be devalued 36 times in 1989. ``This economy is like a very sick patient, a vegetable that's kept alive purely through tubes,'' said Gilberto Cuadra, president of the Superior Council of Private Enterprise, Nicaragua's leading business group. Unlike Gurdian, Cuadra doesn't think he could deal with the Sandinistas in power until 1996, comparing it to ``a marriage between a dead person and a live one.'' ``It just doesn't work,'' he added, saying the Sandinistas have lost their confidence. ``We have nothing more to do. If things don't change, it's not worthwhile to keep producing.'' Business leaders still remember the many coffee farms the Sandinistas confiscated, some as recently as last year. Many businessmen say the seizures were acts of vengeance against Sandinista opponents. More recently, the president, in a speech at a political rally, threatened to confiscate a cooking oil factory managed by the son-in-law of opposition presidential candidate Violeta Barrios de Chamorro. ``Even if the (Sandinista) Front wins crystal-clear elections, it still won't attract the trust of foreign investors,'' one Latin American diplomat said.

DOC.HEAD: Archbishop Desmond Tutu Appeals To Harvard to Divest
With AM-South Africa
DOC.TEXT: Archbishop Desmond Tutu urged fellow members of a Harvard University governing board Sunday to back divestment in South Africa until changes promised by that country's president become reality. In a news conference following a closed-door meeting of the Board of Overseers, Tutu said that much of what South African President F.W. de Klerk said last week was a declaration of purpose. ``Sanctions should remain in place until certain conditions are met,'' Tutu said. In last week's speech, de Klerk promised to free jailed African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela and lift government bans on 30 outlawed opposition groups. Tutu, who won the 1984 Nobel Peace Prize for his anti-apartheid efforts, welcomed the announcement but tempered his response with pragmatism. ``We'd like to see these things immediately but let's be realistic.
