The parliamentary session has just begun,'' the Anglican archbishop said. Tutu said he had asked colleagues on the 30-member Board of Overseers to press Harvard to withdraw $139 million in investments in South African companies until Mandela is freed, all exiled political activists are granted amnesty and the government's policy of segregation is dismantled. The board planned to further consider the divestment issue at a future meeting. The board is less powerful than the university's main governing body, the Harvard Corp., but is the only alumni-elected panel with an influence on school policy. The board plays no role in day-to-day business, but must give formal consent to major initiaitves and appointments. Tutu, who ran for the board on an anti-apartheid slate, was elected last June along with U.S. Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole and actor John Lithgow. The archbishop said de Klerk's action last week was sparked by the growing number of countries that had placed sanctions on South Africa, a position Tutu said seemed to be catching on among fellow board members. He said he was encouraged by the attention South Africa had received in the United States amid the historic changes in the Soviet bloc. ``The kind of coverage and response is indicative that, in spite of what has happened in Eastern Europe, which pushed our case to the back burner, people here do want to see our situation resolved,'' he said. Asked why he was in Massachusetts rather than South Africa at such a critical time, Tutu replied, ``Harvard is Harvard. The things that Harvard does and does not do have an impact far beyond what you would expect from an educational institution.''

DOC.HEAD: China Launches Telecommunications Satellite
DOC.TEXT: China on Sunday evening launched its fifth telecommunications satellite from the Xichang space center in the southwestern province of Sichuan, the official Xinhua News Agency reported. The satellite, launched by a Long March 3 rocket, was moving into its designated orbit and all instruments were functioning normally, the report said. Premier Li Peng, army Chief of Staff Chi Haotian and Central Military Commission Vice Chairman Liu Huaqing watched the blastoff either from Xichang or on a monitoring screen at the Beijing Command Center, the news agency said. Like all previous launches, it was not announced publicly beforehand. It was the 26th launch to put a satellite into space since China's space program began in 1970. Xinhua said the launch ``proves once again that China's telecommunications satellite technology is mature enough to provide launching services for the international market.'' China, which is aggressively promoting its services, in April is scheduled to put into orbit its first non-Chinese satellite, AsiaSat, an American-made communications satellite owned by a Hong Kong-based company. That launch was jeopardized by U.S. economic sanctions imposed after China's crackdown on the pro-democracy movement in June, but President Bush in December agreed to waive the ban on exporting the satellite to China.

DOC.HEAD: New Age Community Planned in Hill Country
DOC.TEXT: A Texan and his partners want to create a New Age-style community called the City of Immortals and based on ideas by Maharishi Mahesh Yogi, leader of the Transcendental Meditation movement. What is now a rustic 250-acre patch of Hill Country would be the first of what the Maharishi and his followers envision as a worldwide movement to fashion largely self-contained residential areas free of crime, pollution _ and anxiety. The Maharishi, whose students have included the Beatles, popularized Transcendental Meditation in the 1960s. Construction of the first of 100 homes in the City of Immortals could begin as early as spring, said Walter Reifslager of Charter Development Group. The homes will be built with essentially toxic-free materials and gasoline-powered cars will have to be parked on the outskirts of the community, the Austin man said. There is talk of a Maharishi-style theme park. Homes would cost between $200,000 and the ``seven-figure range,'' Reifslager said. ``We had a concept, and then we heard about the (Maharishi's) Heaven on Earth approach,'' Reifslager said in a recent interview. ``It so epitomized what we had been thinking about doing ... That's when we decided to pursue building a Heaven on Earth project.'' The proposed development between Driftwood and Oak Hill about 30 miles southwest of downtown Austin has raised concerns in this quiet region. ``I can tell you, frankly, that there are people in this community who are adamant in opposition to these people,'' said Rev. Joel C. Thielepape, pastor of the nearby Friendship Baptist Church. ``They feel there is something to be feared by this development.'' Thielepape said he has no major problems with the development, partly because the rural county has been exposed already to disciples of Transcendental Meditation. A nearby subdivision known as Radiance was developed several years ago by Transcendental Meditation practitioners. Last December a plan to create a City of Immortals west of Tulsa, Okla., drew the attention of such groups as the Oklahoma Cult Awareness Network. An unidentified network spokesman told the Dallas Morning News he was worried that the Maharishi's group is organized along the same lines as many destructive cults, a claim hotly denied by Transcendental Meditation backers. Reifslager said he and his associates have already interviewed potential home buyers and that one home has already been designed. He said the project is not being marketed strictly to those who practice Transcendental Meditation, and that no one in the community will be compelled to practice it. The Hill Country is not the only proposed site for Maharishi-style communities. Curtis McDonald, vice president of Heaven on Earth Development Corp. based in Malibu, Calif., said his company has been working to locate communities near Houston, Denver, San Francisco, Los Angeles, San Diego, Washington, D.C.; Toronto and in southeastern Iowa.

DOC.HEAD: Former Atlanta Mayor To Announce For Governor Monday
DOC.TEXT: Former Atlanta Mayor Andrew Young plans to announce his candidacy for governor of Georgia Monday night, and said he hopes to win the nomination outright in the primary. ``My campaign folk get upset when I say this, but I don't want a runoff,'' Young told a meeting of the Southside Public Officials last week, when he revealed his plans to make a formal announcement. Young, who is trying to become the state's first black governor, shares the lead with four-term Lt. Gov. Zell Miller in some Democratic polls. The race also includes state Sen. Roy E. Barnes and state Rep. Lauren W. McDonald Jr., who is backed by powerful House Speaker Tom Murphy and former Gov. Lester Maddox. The number of hopefuls in the field likely will make it very difficult for any candidate to get the 50 percent plus one vote needed to win the primary outright, said Robert S. Kahn, Barnes' campaign manager. The primary is set for July 17, and a runoff would be held Aug. 7. Young has been raising campaign money, without making a formal announcement. ``Fire in the belly, I think, stems from raw ambition,'' he said in an interview. ``I don't have that. My ambition is to serve, and I have been driven to serve because that's what makes life worthwhile.'' Young said he plans to start the campaign immediately, touring the state in a van. Campaign workers had planned a flying tour, but Young rejected it. ``They started talking about a tarmac-to-tarmac,'' Young said. ``That's not me. We have to go meet with people.'' Last fall, Virginia made L. Douglas Wilder the first black ever elected governor.

DOC.HEAD: Survivors Describe Helplessness, Terror During Bus Attack
With AM-Israel-Bus Attack
DOC.TEXT: Survivors of the deadly attack Sunday on a bus carrying Israeli tourists in the Egyptian desert described the terror of being trapped in the vehicle with nowhere to run. ``The vehicle became like hell at once, there were shots from every direction, grenades were thrown inside the bus and everything was covered with smoke. Holes appeared in several places in the bus,'' said Dr. Yigal Barak, one of 31 Israelis on board. At least eight people were killed and 17 wounded when two masked men fired machine guns and hurled hand grenades at the bus near Ismailiya, a city on the Suez Canal 40 miles east of Cairo, an Egyptian government statement said. ``Everyone saw his death in front of his eyes,'' said Barak, speaking on army radio in a telephone interview from an Ismailiya hospital. He was not injured. ``It seemed like an eternity, but in fact it lasted for several minutes only. Then there was a total quiet, and only screams were heard. Bodies were scattered everywhere,'' he said. The bus' passengers included a group of doctors and some officials of Egypt's Tourism Ministry. It was traveling to Cairo from Rafah, a divided town on the Egyptian-Israeli border in the Sinai Peninsula. Army radio's correspondent in Cairo quoted another survivor, Miriam Kadmon, as saying the driver of the car signaled to the bus to stop. The guerrillas then smashed the car's rear window and opened fire. An Egyptian, screaming, jumped off the bus and was shot, she was quoted as saying. Ms. Kadmon said the two men got out of the car, continuing to fire at the bus and also threw hand grenades at it, army radio reported. Barak said he could not see the attackers but could hear both firing from outside and from the open doors of the bus. ``Several people jumped out and and I'm afraid they were either wounded or killed,'' Barak said. ``There was a terrible fear and the feeling of helplessness. Nobody could protect us, nobody carried any weapons.'' Barak said Egyptian motorists who passed the scene refused to stop and a group of police officers and soldiers who arrived later were afraid to approach the bus, ``because there were several live grenades around it.'' Late Sunday, Israel sent a Hercules plane with a medical team aboard to Cairo to evacuate the victims, the army said. Three survivors _ Ms. Kadmon, and Dr. Michael Cooper and his wife _ returned to Israel early Monday on an El Al Israel airlines flight from Cairo, but airport police prevented reporters from speaking with them. The women were not hurt but Cooper suffered a shrapnel wound to the eye. An anonymous caller speaking to a Western news agency in Cairo claimed responsibility for the attack on behalf of the Organization for the Defense of Oppressed in Egyptian Prisons, a previously unknown group.

DOC.HEAD: IRS Again Investigating Scientologists
DOC.TEXT: The Internal Revenue Service is taking on the Church of Scientology in federal court, contending that its worldwide spiritual headquarters in Clearwater is a business and should be paying taxes. Scientologists vehemently disagree, calling the IRS corrupt and accusing it of pursuing a vendetta against Scientology. ``We feel the federal government should investigate illegal drug running in Florida and should investigate money laundering in Florida banks,'' spokesman Humberto Fontana told the St. Petersburg Times in a story published Sunday. The Clearwater group pays no Pinellas County property taxes on its church buildings, and has paid income taxes only once. Scientologists also are in court with Pinellas County over the organization's tax-exempt status. The federal government has asked for 47 categories of documents for 1985, 1986 and 1987 that the Scientologists say would number more than 50,000 pages. The Scientologists refused, but did agree to explain some aspects of their financing in response to specific questions from the IRS. That material has entered the public file in U.S. District Court in Tampa. A similar case involving the Church of Scientology of California took 18 years to resolve after the U.S. Supreme Court refused to hear a Scientology appeal. The Clearwater Scientology branch has been secretive about its finances. But the case has prompted it to disclose for the first time that their organization pays annual operating expenses of $26 million. It said it sends millions of dollars each year to Scientology organizations elsewhere, including $14.5 million for literature and supplies, $4.5 million for ``dissemination and expansion,'' $2.4 million for ``advanced technology,'' and $1.3 million for films, all in 1987, the last year for which the Scientologists provided figures. The Clearwater branch said it pools reserve accounts with more than 100 other Scientology organizations. The pool in 1987 had assets of $206 million, liabilities of $165.6 million and a net worth of $40.4 million. According to the new court documents, the Clearwater base has a staff of 700 to 1,100. Scientology began with L. Ron Hubbard, an energetic writer with flaming red hair who was known for his rollicking Western tales and fanciful science-fiction stories. In the early 1950s, Hubbard began writing about a religion that he named Scientology. He spread the word about the benefits of ``auditing,'' a sort of counseling process that involves a device called an E-meter and thousands of dollars in auditing fees. Court records reveal that non-staff Scientologists who persuade someone to undergo auditing can receive 10 percent of the auditing fee. Those who persuade someone to take religious training can receive 15 percent of the course fee. In 1987, the Clearwater organization paid commissions of $14.6 million.

DOC.HEAD: Candidate Says He Didn't Know Use of Homosexual Epithet Was Offensive
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Some readers may find material offensive.
DOC.TEXT: A California assemblyman who called a group of homosexual protesters ``faggots'' said he was unaware that the term was offensive but still refuses to apologize. ``I didn't even know that faggot was a derogatory term ... that's what I've always heard them called. I know that people don't call them queers any more,'' Assemblyman Gil Ferguson said Saturday. ``I won't call them gay, though,'' Ferguson said. ``I don't think there's anything gay about it. It's depressing.'' Ferguson, a Republican running for the state Senate, was picketed by a homosexual rights group earlier in the day during a campaign appearance in this Orange County community. ``I don't care about them,'' Ferguson told reporters. ``I'm a retired Marine. A couple of faggots out there aren't going to scare me.'' Ferguson is running in a special election Tuesday in a heavily Republican state Senate District, which is split between Los Angeles and Orange counties. He was picketed during an appearance at the Power Community Church with the Rev. Louis B. Sheldon, who strongly backed anti-homosexual measures on several city ballots last November. Ferguson later said he meant no harm but would not ``back down'' from the comment. ``I have learned since this morning that they have style manuals about etiquette and what you're supposed to call people,'' Ferguson said. ``I could have called them sodomites.'' Some of Ferguson's seven opponents attacked his remarks. ``That's awful,'' Democrat Janice Graham said. ``I might think gays are wrong, but to try to publicly demean them by using words like `faggots' or `queers.' I think Mr. Ferguson should have stopped and thought about that,'' said Diamond Bar City Councilman Gary Miller, a Republican. During last year's Republican state convention, Ferguson wrote a resolution calling on the party to ban clubs based on sexual orientation. It was rejected by state Republican leaders, including U.S. Sen. Pete Wilson and Gov. George Deukmejian.

DOC.HEAD: Reagan Accepts Award At House of Hope
DOC.TEXT: Former President Reagan praised the House of Hope for its work with troubled girls and received its first humanitarian award at a fund-raising banquet Sunday night. In presenting the award, shelter founder Sara Trollinger recounted the Reagans' involvement in the House of Hope. While visiting Orlando in 1985, Reagan read an article about the non-profit shelter, which receives no government money, and sent the home a personal check for $1,000. In September 1987, he presented it with a certificate of appreciation in promoting children's safety and in 1988 he recorded a three-minute videotape ``challenging citizens to look to the House of Hope as a model'' for homes for troubled teen-agers across the nation. Trollinger founded the shelter in May 1985 with just $200. She started asking for grants and bought the home's current site with a grant from the Philip Crosby Foundation. Crosby underwrote Sunday's banquet so that all the proceeds of the $300-a-plate dinner attended by 700 people will go to the House of Hope. The shelter, which now houses 19 girls ages 12 to 17, provides a home and a Christian education. The girls must be willing to give up alcohol, drugs, rock music and their peers to begin a Christian life which includes counseling and discipline, Trollinger said. ``If I ever saw anyone put by God on this Earth for a purpose it was Sara Trollinger,'' Reagan said.

DOC.HEAD: Man Accused of Computer Extortion Says He Was Set Up
DOC.TEXT: An international consultant arrested by the FBI on computer extortion charges said he may have been set up by the United Nations agency he worked for. Joseph L. Popp Jr., an anthropologist from suburban Willowick, told his attorney on Saturday he was working with the backing of World Health Organization officials who may have set him up as a ``fall guy,'' the lawyer said. WHO spokesman Thomas W. Netter said from the U.N. agency's Geneva headquarters Sunday that the accusation that WHO was involved in the scheme ``is totally and completely false.'' Netter said he did not know whether Popp had ever worked for WHO. Popp, 39, was arrested Thursday on a federal fugitive warrant stemming from charges by Britain's Scotland Yard. He is charged with mailing 20,000 to 26,000 computer disks ostensibly providing information about AIDS but actually containing a ``virus'' program that prevented computers from accessing other information. The disks were sent to businesses, hospitals and church organizations, including the Vatican. The program ended with a message telling users to send up to $378 to the Panama post office box of PC Cyborg Corp. for a second disk making the computer usable again, federal officials said. Popp's attorney, John P. Kilroy, said his client told him that he did not set up PC Cyborg Corp. In a statement released through Kilroy, Popp said, ``The sole reason for the project was to use computers to provide health education to people around the world to fight the global epidemic of AIDS. I never made a penny off of this, and I never intended to.'' Popp provided AIDS education in Africa under contract with the WHO, Kilroy said. Popp has never been director, shareholder or an employee of PC Cyborg, Kilroy said, and had no financial interest in the company. Kilroy said Popp told him that Cyborg directors are WHO officials and that some of them have used aliases, apparently to prevent the project's being traced to them should it fail. ``He's certain they're going to deny any knowledge or participation,'' Kilroy added. Popp is being held without bond at the Justice Center in Cleveland.

DOC.HEAD: Pittston Co. Reports Fourth Quarter Loss of $18.8 Million
DOC.TEXT: The Pittston Co., citing costs of a settlement of a nine-month strike at its coal division by the United Mine Workers, reported a fourth-quarter loss of $18.8 million. The loss, which amounted to 50 cents a share, compared with net income of $15.2 million or 40 cents a share a year earlier, Pittston said. Revenues fell to $404 million in the quarter from $413 million a year earlier. The fourth-quarter results include $16.2 million worth of special charges, most of which were related to the company's coal business, Pittston Chairman Paul W. Douglas said Saturday. The charge covers costs related to the labor settlement, a return to normal working operations, some writedowns of coal assets, the anticipation of losses on certain coal sales contracts and a reserve for unrelated litigation. Douglas said Pittston's coal activities reported a fourth quarter operating loss of $25.2 million, including the special charges. About 1,500 coal miners who had been working without a contract for 14 months went on strike at Pittston mines in Virginia and West Virginia in April. After negotiations overseen by federal mediators, the company and UMW officials reached a tentative contract agreement on Jan. 1. The agreement has yet to be ratified by UMW members. For all of 1989, Pittston's net income fell 92 percent to $3.8 million, or 10 cents a share, from $48.6 million, or $1.26 a share, in 1988. Revenues rose to $1.63 billion from $1.58 billion. Pittston is the parent company of Burlington Air Express and the Brink's security companies, as well as Pittston Coal Group.

DOC.HEAD: Pan Am Hinting at Possible Deal with Northwest, Union Official Says
DOC.TEXT: Pan American World Airways is indicating that it may announce a deal with Northwest Airlines, the subject of a bidding war that Pan Am lost to investor Alfred Checchi last year, a union official said. William F. Genoese, director of the Teamsters airline division, said Pan Am management had leaked word that a major announcement _ probably a deal with Northwest _ will come out of its board meeting this Tuesday. In a statement over the weekend, Genoese said Pan Am's teamsters will strike the carrier if workers' rights aren't protected in any kind of merger. The union did not strike after Pan Am imposed a contract settlement on the Teamsters in February 1988. Jeff Kriendler, a spokesman for Pan Am, said the airline's board of directors had a regularly scheduled meeting on Tuesday, but he said the company did not comment on topics before the board. Pan Am last year offered about $3.3 billion for NWA Inc., Northwest's parent, but was outbid by a $4 billion offer from a group led by Checchi. Suffering from years of losses and a small domestic route base, Pan Am has been looking for a merger partner as a possible solution for some time and continues to do so, Kriendler said.
